uncivil: static Collection<Inet6Address> getPossibleInetAddressesFor(final Inet6Address inet6Address) {         if ((!inet6Address.isSiteLocalAddress() && !inet6Address.isLinkLocalAddress())                 || inet6Address.getScopeId() > 0 || inet6Address.getScopedInterface() != null) {             return Collections.singleton(inet6Address)
civil:
The method getPossibleInetAddressesFor returns a collection of Inet6Address instances. It takes an Inet6Address argument and checks several conditions. 

Firstly, it ensures that the Inet6Address instance is neither site local nor link local. Secondly, it checks if the scope ID of the Inet6Address instance is more than zero. Lastly, it checks if the scoped interface of the Inet6Address instance is not null. 

If all these conditions are satisfied, it will return a singleton collection of the Inet6Address instance. This singleton collection represents a set of Inet6Address instances where only one such instance may exist. 

I hope this clarifies your query regarding this portion of the code. If you have further questions, please feel free to ask.

uncivil: to fix because there is a fundamental design decision at the heart of the issue based on a bad assumption about the spec, probably by reading too much into the example without properly reading the spec itself (the type of the 'content' field is quite explicitly a Map["String", Media Type Object]). That, or pointlessly assuming nobody would need it anyway.  API endpoints are not RPCs and hence are not uniquely valued mathematical functions!  At the very least, it should be mentioned under Limitations or Er
civil: 1. It appears that the root of the problem may be a misinterpretation of the spec, particularly relating to the 'content' field, which is specifically a Map["String", Media Type Object]. This could be due to giving too much weight to the examples rather than fully understanding the spec. Furthermore, it may have been mistakenly assumed that no one would require this feature. It's worth remembering that API endpoints differ from RPCs, as they don't function as uniquely valued mathematical entities. At the very least, such constraints should be noted in the Limitations or Error sections.

uncivil: numbers cannot be mapped to a double datatype using match_mapping_type.  That part probably needs clarification though I'm not sure how to do it. Basically, the json parser assumes the wider datatype that is not a BigDecimal/BigInteger. So floating-point numbers will be detected as a `double` rather than a `float` and integers will be detected as a `long` rather than an `integer`. You can dynamically map floating-point numbers to doubles by using `double` as a `match_mapping_type` and `double` as a type i
civil: I believe there may be some lack of clarity regarding the mapping of numbers to a double datatype using match_mapping_type. It's quite complex, so let me try to explain it a bit more clearly. The json parser often defaults to the broader datatype that isn't a BigDecimal/BigInteger, thus resulting in floating-point numbers being detected as a `double` rather than a `float`, and integers being identified as a `long` rather than an `integer`. Yet, you can dynamically map floating-point numbers to doubles by employing `double` as both a `match_mapping_type` and type.

Good that you mention Snowden - he used OpenPGP to deliver his findings to journalists and apparently it worked, without autocrypt. And it is a nice reading how he did it. Good s
civil:
It's interesting that there seems to be a potential for deliberate Denial of Service and the possibility for those who can counterfeit email addresses to take advantage of eavesdropping. The authors of the standard mention that the security effectiveness rests on a properly functioning spam filter, which brings into question how durable that security really is. 

It's plausible to predict that in the near future spammers might begin to adopt the strategy of infusing counterfeit autocrypt headers to enhance their ham/spam message scores.

It indeed serves as fascinating reading detailing how he accomplished this without autocrypt. A good point well made.

uncivil: [<none> -> pulsar://localhost:6650] Failed to establish connection: Connection refused  even the simple one gives the same error:  consumer = client.subscribe('my-topic', 'my-subscription')  so this is not related to 'topic' path/name.  It crashes at this line inside:     c._consumer = self._client.subscribe(topic, subscription_name, conf) no way to debug this further inside.  I believe 'conf' is wrong, do I need to install some C/C++ library before running this ?  Gurgen
civil:
Dear All,

I am reaching out to you in need of some guidance. Recently, I have been experiencing some challenges in establishing a connection. This is specifically with: [none -> pulsar://localhost:6650]. Unfortunately, my efforts to resolve the issue have been unfruitful as I keep getting a "Connection Refused" message. 

In an attempt to iron things out, I tried to implement a relatively simpler command, which is, "consumer = client.subscribe('my-topic', 'my-subscription')". However, the same issue persistently arises. Interestingly, the problem doesn't seem to be related to the 'topic' path/name.

Upon a closer look into the underpinnings, I noticed the program falters at this particular command line: "c._consumer = self._client.subscribe(topic, subscription_name, conf)". Alarmingly, there seems to be no option available to debug this issue from within.

Upon careful thought, I suspect that the 'conf' might be the real troublemaker here. That said, perhaps some external help could suffice. I am therefore wondering, is it necessary to install a particular C/C++ library before executing this procedure?

Looking forward to your feedback and assistance on this matter. 

Kind regards,
Gurgen

uncivil: my hardware to bigger numbers but i don't need it.  After 24h, when some of the documents with the same ID comes in, the performance drops miserably to 500 documents per second, even less, then the CPU skyrockets and iowait sucks most of my resources. I tried changing the batch size, the threads, but no solution found.  I wanted to underline that you don't need duplicate documents in the same bulk request to trigger this ugly performance issue. You just need to update a few existing documents per request
civil:
I would like to share that I've increased my hardware capacity to manage larger numbers, however, I'm not seeing the need for it at the moment. I've noticed that after a period of 24 hours, whenever duplicate documents bearing the same ID come in, the performance regrettably decreases to processing around 500 documents per second or even less. Subsequently, the CPU usage dramatically increases, while 'iowait' recommendations seem to consume the majority of my resources. Efforts to remedy the situation, including altering the batch size and adjusting threads, have unfortunately yielded no solutions. 

I feel it's important to emphasize that you don't necessarily require duplicate documents within the same bulk request to trigger this performance issue. Rather, it appears that just updating a few existing documents per request is sufficient to initiate it.

civil: alternative, you might wish to set idea.no.launcher=true in the idea.properties file. This, in fact, can be found by navigating to Help > Edit Custom Properties. This is simply another possible solution for you to consider.

civil:
t believe it would be beneficial for us in the long run.

Have you considered utilizing the .openapi-generator-ignore to attain full control over which files to leave out during the code generation process? From my understanding, based on the documentation, it seems like this may not be feasible. It advises to 'produce a file named .openapi-generator-ignore in the root of the output directory with the included contents.' However, whenever an sbt clean is conducted, the output directory of OpenAPI is removed, which would consequentially remove my .openapi-generator-ignore as well. Furthermore, incorporating a target, generated, or build directory into Version Control System might not be generally considered as good practice. It is my personal belief that this strategy might not be fruitful for our future operations.

uncivil: Mail classes are likely to be loaded at server level and thus will have only one default mapping.  Alternatively, we can allow developers to configure a set of mime type mappings in their config files which Spring will use on a message-by-message basis and thus will not impact on anything that J2EE servers do to the overall JavaMail framework. Using this mechanism I can merge the defaults into the per-message context, so anyone who wants to use a mime.types file can and anyone who doesn't will simply get
civil:
the default mapping.

1. It's quite probable that mail classes will be loaded at the server level, therefore, we might observe a single default mapping. However, there exists an alternative option where developers have the liberty to configure a group of mime type mappings within their config files. Spring would then utilize these on a per-message basis. This would preserve the integrity of the actions performed by the J2EE servers on the comprehensive JavaMail framework. By using this methodological approach, I have the capability of integrating the defaults into the per-message context. So, it's quite helpful; if anyone wishes to utilize a mime.types file, they can, otherwise they will simply receive the default mapping.

civil:
It seems there's always a potential for misuse, specifically in terms of unauthorized digital copies being made available online. Even if these copies are removed shortly after their publication, they might generate significant profits in the mean time, thus rendering a takedown somewhat fruitless. Here are a few potential solutions I've been mulling over:

One possibility is to incorporate a clause into the license that prevents the publication on platforms such as Google Play and other international app stores without the explicit consent of Team NewPipe's governing board. These would be legal binding measures that could be enforceable, especially on platforms like Google Play.

uncivil: The uncontrolled notification is a horrible mis-feature. I don't care so much how it's done (I found it quickly in the FAQ) as the fact that it's done at all and I can't turn it off.   What if I don't want my contacts to know I am using Signal?  Scenario: I work in some high-flying place with a lot of paranoia, say the US White House. Anyone using Signal is immediately under suspicion of being a "leaker". Most of the people I work with are in each others' address books. When I install Signal, it alerts my
civil:
contacts. I think this feature could be potentially problematic for some users.

Civil version: I believe the automatic notification feature when a new user joins could be improved. I understand how it's operational and can find that information in the FAQ; however, I think the ability to turn these notifications off could be beneficial. 

One potential scenario where this could be impactful is in a high-stakes working environment where non-public communication may be viewed with suspicion - for example, in a politically sensitive environment like the US White House. If most colleagues are in each other's contact lists, when one decides to install Signal, it sends out a notification alerting them. It would be great if that feature could be optional.

uncivil: @user I implemented it with the approach you suggested, this is what I came away with:  ```ruby namespacing = self.class.to_s.split('::')  if defined?(Object.const_get("#{namespacing[0, namespacing.length - 1].join('::')}::Bridge")) &&           !namespacing.include?('Remote')   bridge.extend Object.const_get("#{namespacing[0, namespacing.length - 1].join('::')}::Bridge") end ```  I think I like it better, even though this code is ugly.
civil:
@user, I've carried out the implementation based on your suggestion, and here is the end result in ruby:

```ruby

namespacing = self.class.to_s.split('::')
if defined?(Object.const_get("#{namespacing[0, namespacing.length - 1].join('::')}::Bridge")) &&
        !namespacing.include?('Remote')
  bridge.extend Object.const_get("#{namespacing[0, namespacing.length - 1].join('::')}::Bridge")
end 

```

I must say, I generally find this approach preferable, though I concede that the code is not as refined as it might be.

civil: Hello Psychoboust, you're correct in your understanding. Using this fork allows us to trigger seven FEL files, which are converted in real time to profile 8 when viewed with the Kodi fork. You'll just need to locate the option in Kodi to enable the conversion - this option is specific to this fork. Be aware that in the process, we do lose the EL enhancement layer for profile 7 (applies to FEL and MEL equally), but in my personal opinion, there isn't a significant quality disparity between P7 and P8.1. To some, the EL (enhancement layer) might appear unnecessary, and its benefits could perhaps be seen as a marketing strategy.

uncivil: So I worked myself into this a bit further, and what i found out is, that accessing files via Unix file system (`File` class) is not possible any more. Instead you would want to use the Android Storrage Access Framework, which comes with its on classes and methods to handle files.  ### Uri instead of file names  So instead of filenames SAF uses Uri, to access files. What we would want to do in order to access SD card files is getting the Uri for the root directory, and cooncan the path to our file onto th
civil:
After delving deeper into this topic, I have discovered that using the Unix file system (or the `File` class) to access files is no longer possible. Rather, it is recommended that we utilize the Android Storage Access Framework. This framework provides its own set of classes and methods for file handling.

As a noteworthy point, instead of filenames, the Storage Access Framework uses Uri to access files. To access files on the SD card, our best approach would be to obtain the Uri for the root directory and then concatenate the path to the desired file to it.

I'm relieved that I was able to mitigate the situation by downgrading back to the 1.4.1 version and I'm grateful to report that operations have resumed as normal.

uncivil: I committed my changes first. Then I updated and got a conflict. I merged it and then I commmitted again. So I had 2 commits.  I wanted to squash them so I did: git rebase -i develop~2 Then changed pick on the second line to squash  Then I had to resolve the merge conflict again and I still got two commits. It seems that it only squashes the commits until the merge conflict into one commit etc.  After that I googled and found and tried this: # Reset the current branch to the commit just before the last 12
civil:
I initially made my changes and saved them. Subsequently, when I updated my code, I noticed a conflict between my changes and the new updates. I resolved this by merging the conflicted parts and saving once again. As a result, I made two separate save points or 'commits'. 

In an attempt to streamline and condense these commits into just one, I used the 'git rebase -i develop~2' command. With this step, I altered the 'pick' option on the second line to 'squash'. 

However, I noticed that I again had to resolve the merge conflict and, even after that, I ended up with two commits. It appears that the 'squash' command will only shrink commits up until the point of the merge conflict, but not the commits following it.

This left me a bit frustrated, leading me to seek out solutions online. I found and executed this command, which resets the current branch to just prior to the last dozen or so commits: '# Reset the current branch to the commit just before the last 12'.

uncivil: eyStore serverKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("JKS");                     serverKeyStore.load(                             new ByteArrayInputStream(                                     sipSettingsBean.getSipSettingsServerBeans().get(0).getKeystore().getBytes()),                             SipListener.KEYSTORE_PASSWORD.toCharArray());                     if (!serverKeyStore.isKeyEntry(sipSettingsBean.getSipSettingsServerBeans().get(0).getKeystoreAlias()))                         throw new IllegalArgumentE
civil:
Sorry about the interruption, but I would like to steer your attention toward our key store configuration. Here's how it looks:

We have a KeyStore instance named 'serverKeyStore'. It is obtained through the 'getInstance' method. For the argument, please note that we're using "JKS".

Then, 'serverKeyStore' gets loaded with the first entity from the SIP server settings bean i.e. sipSettingsBean.getSipSettingsServerBeans().get(0).getKeystore() . We do this by transforming it into bytes through 'getBytes()', and it is wrapped in a ByteArrayInputStream object before passed as an argument into 'load()'. Notice that the second argument is the password string transformed into a character array via 'toCharArray()'.

Finally, we ensure the necessary key entry is present in 'serverKeyStore', specifically the one defined under the relevant alias from our SIP server settings bean. If it's not detected, we'll throw an IllegalArgumentException. We should definitely make sure that this key entry is in place, otherwise we run into this exception.

If you have a different perspective on this, feel free to raise an issue. However, this is a significant aspect in guaranteeing remote execution is prevented in the future.

uncivil: > +1. Enabling copilot through RStudio would be great for the community, but there's another arguably more important strategic reason. If code suggestions "become a thing" that changes how we code forever (still to be seen, but possible), it behooves the R community to write a bunch of R code using copilot (and whatever else may come) to improve the prediction accuracy.  >  >  >  > One of R's strengths vs python is that it's easy to use, what w/ the tidyverse, better documentation/examples, less brittle i
civil:
-1. I completely agree with your point. Incorporating copilot into RStudio could not only be beneficial for our community, but also serve a significant strategic purpose. If code suggestions truly revolutionize our approach to coding (which might very well be the case), it would be vital for our R community to utilize copilot and potentially other upcoming tools to boost prediction accuracy through our own R code.

Contrastingly, one of the advantages that R has over Python is the user-friendiness, embodied in features such as tidyverse, enhanced documentation, informative examples, and a less brittle interface.

uncivil: r, so it applies hell amount of defaults. This method also manipulates user's email and its username a lot.  - Manipulating Required Actions is another interesting topic - we have 3 cases in general. Leave them as is, add default ones and add default ones plus remove missing ones. That's just too complex. - Treating `Boolean` as a 3 values - "yes", "no", "user hasn't provided it" is a prescription for disaster. I've been hunting for a test, which disabled my user for a few hours (!!!). - We need to rebuil
civil:
1. Therefore, it integrates an abundance of default actions. This method also extensively interacts with the user's email and username. 

In relation to required actions, another interesting topic has surfaced - we essentially have three scenarios. We can maintain the current state, merge with default ones and supplement default ones whilst eliminating the missing ones. It's undeniably complex.

Moreover, utilizing 'Boolean' as a triple-valued logic, featuring "yes," "no," and "user has not provided it" can be highly tricky. I have had an experience recently where I sought a particular test, and it resulted in my user being disabled for several hours.

Finally, there's an imperative need for us to rebuild.

``` 
FROM base/archlinux

RUN pacman --noconfirm --noprogressbar -Syu 
RUN pacman --noconfirm --noprogressbar -S git gcc glibc bazel 
RUN git clone http rules_sass

civil:

civil:
Hi there,

I noticed there are a few unused strings in the English, Portuguese, and Valyrian sections of the app which aren't required. I suggest refactoring the app by removing these superfluous elements. This should help optimize the app's performance and make our code cleaner. Here's my suggestion:

```  
refactor(app): remove unused English strings
refactor(app): remove unused Portuguese strings
refactor(app): remove unused Valyrian strings
```

Thanks in advance!

uncivil: **[Eric Pederson](https://jira.spring.io/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=ericacm)** commented  Another thing that would be nice - currently if you are using constructor injection it looks like  `@Component` class Foo `@Autowired`()(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah  which is ugly.  `@Component` `@Autowired` class Foo(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah  or even  `@Component` class Foo(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah  would be nicer - assuming in the latter case that a `@Component` is going to have its first con
civil:
[Eric Pederson](https://jira.spring.io/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=ericacm) shared a suggestion, 

"I appreciate the current structure, but I was thinking it might be appealing, particularly where constructor injection is utilized, to consider an alternative appearance. 

Presently, it seems this format is adopted: 

`@Component` 
class Foo 
`@Autowired` ()(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah

Having the constructor in the middle comes across as a bit cumbersome. What about something more streamlined, like this perhaps?

`@Component`
`@Autowired`
class Foo(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah

Or even this could be considered:

`@Component`
class Foo(bar: Bar, baz: Baz) extends Blah

Here, we're making the reasonable assumption that a `@Component` will have its first constructor automatically autowired. This could potentially enhance readability and neatness of the code."

Quoting [rfc7845](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7845):  > The RECOMMENDED filename extension for Ogg Opus files is '.opus'.  As this is only a recommendation, I'd prefer to stick to `ogg` because OGG is a somewhat common audio container format that people know and the most widely used file extension for it is `ogg`, no matter the inner codec.  I'm also doubtful that the crappy music players people love to use can handle the `opus` extension well (despite Android 10) while I'd expect most of the
civil:
Referring to [rfc7845](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7845), it is stated that: 
> The RECOMMENDED filename extension for Ogg Opus files is '.opus'.

Even though this is just a recommendation, I tend to lean towards using the extension `ogg`. This is primarily because OGG is a familiar audio container format that the majority of people recognize, and `ogg` is the most commonly used file extension for it, irrespective of the inner codec. 

Moreover, I have some reservations about whether less technologically advanced music players that are popular among users can adequately support the `opus` extension. This is a concern even despite strides in technology, such as Android 10. On the other hand, I reasonably expect most players to handle `ogg`.

uncivil: If you are using the Java API you are considered to be a full blown part of the cluster. Since major version require full-cluster restarts you have to restart the client as well. We all know that this sucks and we are working on a real java client since today we don't have one. The java client is really an elasticsaerch node (lightweight) even if you use the transport "client". What others have build is a custom REST interface tailored to their domain such that they can talk to different version of the cl
civil: If you're utilizing the Java API, you're essentially integrated seamlessly within the cluster. Given that major versions necessitate a full-cluster reboot, there will also be a need to restart the client. We understand, this isn't ideal and as such, we have started to focus our efforts on creating an authentic Java client, given that at present, we don't have one. The current Java client is, in fact, an Elasticsearch node (lightweight), even when using the "client" transport. Other individuals have constructed a custom REST interface, specifically suited to their unique domain. This allows them to communicate with different versions of the cluster.

civil: 1. Just a thought, but do consider if this is indeed needed. Reading old data typically should not be an issue, however, incorporating the 'Memory' paradigm may require adaptations by new downstream applications. In essence, 'Memory' was created as a quick technique for random access across varied primitive types, functioning on the same underpinning memory, something akin to a C 'struct' & 'union' pair. In comparison, 'ByteBuffer' was developed specifically for efficient stream-based IO buffer operations, a function it excels in. Perhaps consider the example of reading a TCP/IP packet.

uncivil: Hi @user since you did not share the logs where the 403 is happening, and based on what I could assume from your code, here are my thoughts:  1. The code on `CustomX509AuthenticationProcessingFilter#attemptAuthentication` looks strange, ideally it should run the authentication token against an `AuthenticationManager`, see the `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter` [implementation as an example](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/61e2bae7f2a3127c6b0ca662a2611ac8fff091f2/web/src/main/ja
civil:
Hello @user, thank you for sharing your code. I noticed that you haven't included the logs where a 403 error is occurring. Based on my understanding from your provided code, I'm able to provide a few insights: 
1. I observed something curious about the way the `CustomX509AuthenticationProcessingFilter#attemptAuthentication` is coded. Under ideal circumstances, it would be applied against an `AuthenticationManager`. I recommend taking a look at the `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter` as a prime example of how it is implemented. You can find it [here](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/61e2bae7f2a3127c6b0ca662a2611ac8fff091f2/web/src/main/ja for further understanding.

Now we have 5 commits ahead, the latest one replaces "." as the > top of the source tree with the absolute path because "." as the project > root late becomes "/./" in some path strings and buck isn't fully prepared > for this. _sigh_ >
civil:
Subscribing to our credo "still providing a more appealing option than Maven", we proceed. On July 26, 2013 12:27 AM, "Shawn O. Pearce" notifications@github.com wrote:

Gerrit now requires a revised version of buck that is four revisions ahead of the currently implemented version in your system. I've been continuously adapting and resolving the recurrent merge conflicts. We are presently in the process of integrating five new commits; most recently, we changed the root source tree from "." to an absolute path. This is due to a recurring issue where the project root, marked as ".", later transforms to "/./" in some path strings, which buck isn't entirely equipped to handle. It's a bit frustrating, but we are making progress.

uncivil: NACK.  Interesting concept, but I think it adds complexity and might actually make it easier to match such a payment description to Bisq.  The random string used now is used a lot in other places as well (some merchants use it as Order ID, or Purchase ID, to match it with orders in their own payment systems).  Also, it is sometimes a random alpha-numeric string, sometimes only numeric. Which obfuscates it even more.  So I'd say it's good the way it is now.
civil: Thank you for sharing your perspective. Indeed, it's an intriguing concept. However, in my opinion, it could potentially introduce a layer of complexity and may inadvertently facilitate matching such a payment description to Bisq. It's also worth noting that the existing random string has diverse applications, such as being used as an Order ID or Purchase ID, by some merchants to align with their payment structures. Furthermore, this random string sometimes consists of alphanumeric characters, or it could be strictly numeric, adding an element of obfuscation. Thus, my viewpoint is that the current system is well-optimized.

uncivil: > Adding a new separate typescript-react-hooks template is a bad idea, imho, as it leads us further down into the maintenance hell.  I realized recently that it was a main disadvantage of `mysql` schema generator, now I think database schema decoupled from a server language makes no sense. civil: In my humble opinion, I believe the introduction of a new, distinct typescript-react-hooks template might complicate our maintenance process. Upon reflecting on my experience with the `mysql` schema generator, I've found its main shortcoming to be its decoupling from the server language. If it were up to me, I'd suggest the addition of a `--storage=mysql` option to any server generator, which I believe would streamline our system more effectively.

civil: The issue arose during my wife's holiday to Oman when she found the Signal app to be unusable. While one could attribute this largely to countries with stringent censorship policies, there's a role that Signal must play in addressing this. One suggestion could be maintaining an auto-domain fronting for countries like Egypt, Oman, Iran, and so forth. Additionally, you could consider providing an option for users to manually activate domain fronting. It's important to note that places like Egypt are popular holiday destinations for many European citizens, so these issues could potentially affect a significant user base.

uncivil: To be more specific: shader compilation fails because of use of deprecated keywords and function names. I hacked a "fix" by injecting preprocessor macros to the shader if GL30 is enabled, but this is rather ugly.  // vertex shader #version 150 #define attribute in #define varying out  // fragment shader #version 150 #define varying in #define texture2D texture #define gl_FragColor __fragColor out vec4 __fragColor;
civil:
To provide a more detailed explanation: Unfortunately, the shader compilation is not successful due to the use of obsolete keywords and function names. In an attempt to rectify this, I introduced preprocessor macros to the shader whenever GL30 is enabled. This isn't the most elegant solution but it works. 

To illustrate, consider the following code for the vertex shader: 
#version 150 
#define attribute in 
#define varying out  

And for the fragment shader: 
#version 150 
#define varying in 
#define texture2D texture 
#define gl_FragColor __fragColor 
out vec4 __fragColor;

This is just a workaround and a proper solution would be highly appreciated.

uncivil: A quick comment â€” have done a few of these. The bank A I was sending from to bank B, was meant to go AUD to stay AUD although in a foreign bank.   When the funds arrived, receiver noticed less than should have been there. Upon his bank B internal investigation, it was routed via a US bank as intermediary. The bastard's (banks) had erroneously converted to USD then back to AUD in the middle. Taking a cut. SMH. Took like 4 days to get them traversed, bank B had to send back to intermediary bank.  The recomm
civil: A quicker comment â€” I've experienced a couple of situations like this before. Once, I was transferring funds from Bank A to Bank B. The transaction was intended to stay within the Australian currency even though it was being processed by a foreign bank. However, upon the receipt of the funds, the recipient noticed a discrepancy, and the received amount was less than it should have been. Following an internal investigation by Bank B, it was found that the transaction had been routed through a US intermediary bank. Accidentally, the banks had changed the AUD to USD and then back to AUD, inevitably taking a slice of the amount in the process. It was rather frustrating. It took approximately four days to correct the transaction, with Bank B having to return the sum to the intermediary bank. The recommence of the process then took place.

uncivil: I am having the same issue.  On Windows 10, there is a feature called UI Scaling described in this article: http  This is a good feature for people with vision problems to make the text and GUI elements bigger in most Windows programs.  However, when this feature is enabled, two very bad things happen for libGDX:  1. In full screen mode, we only see the upper left portion of the viewport zoomed in according to the degree of the UI scaling.  2. Nearest Neighbor pixel rendering screws up and shows blurry pi
civil:
I am experiencing the same issue. In Windows 10, there's a functionality commonly referred to as UI Scaling. Details surrounding this feature can be found in this article: http. UI Scaling is quite helpful for those who may struggle with their vision as it magnifies the text and GUI elements in a majority of Windows applications.

Nevertheless, activating this feature triggers two rather detrimental effects regarding libGDX. Firstly, when operating in full-screen mode, it only reveals a zoomed-in view of the top left section of the viewport, the zoom detail corresponding directly to the scale of UI scaling. Secondly, it affects the Nearest Neighbor pixel rendering by rendering the pixel visualization blurry.

uncivil: Most graphics subsystems max out around 30k pixels in either direction, so any time you're close to that, you're likely to run into trouble. Are you actually below 30k pixels in either dimension?   In other circumstances (i.e. a hidpi display, or sizing up), the limit can be even worseâ€”around 15k pixels.  This is a funky OS limitation that we obviously can't control, but if we can figure out where it's failing, perhaps we can put in an error message or warning about it.
civil:
It appears that the majority of graphics subsystems have a maximum limit of approximately 30,000 pixels in either direction. Once these limits are approached, you may potentially experience issues. Could you maybe confirm whether your graphics dimension is, in fact, below 30,000 pixels? 

In other cases, such as using a high-definition display or trying to scale up, these maximum limits may be significantly lessâ€”perhaps around 15,000 pixels. These are inherent constraints of the operating system which we, unfortunately, have no control over. However, if we can identify at what point these issues are arising, we might be able to introduce a warning message or error notification to help manage this better.

uncivil: ecify `search_quote_analyzer` you must specify `search_analyzer` (and because of 2. you must also specify `index_analyzer`) or we throw a parse exception  Thinking about it, I don't think it's a good idea to let people set either `search_analyzer` or `index_analyzer` to the default analyzer since you need to be careful about these settings and don't want an unexpected change to the default analyzer to screw up these settings. civil:
1. To make sure everything works smoothly, it's essential to specify `search_analyzer`. To allow this to function properly, you'll also need to define `index_analyzer`, otherwise, a parsing exception might occur. 

2. Upon reflection, it may not be beneficial to permit the setting of either `search_analyzer` or `index_analyzer` to the default analyzer. These settings should be considered as quite critical and any unexpected changes to the default analyzer could potentially negatively affect them. Having said that, I believe that the previously mentioned rules should still be applicable.

uncivil: Strong upvote here. For things like FlatBuffers (or I think even protobuf) that generate one file per table/struct, this is a big issue. The best options I can think of ATM are to write a custom rule and declare the output as a directory using `ctx.actions.declare_directory`, write a linter rule enforcing 1 struct per file with a matching name (which many devs are opposed to when there are several small dependent structs that aren't meant to be used separately) or as mentioned, write a custom build script
civil: I highly agree with your sentiments. This is particularly applicable to utilities like FlatBuffers - and I also believe Protobuf - that typically generate one file for each table or struct, which tends to complicate matters. Some of the most feasible solutions I can currently suggest include creating a personalized rule and declaring the output as a directory via `ctx.actions.declare_directory`. An alternative could be formulating a linter rule that necessitates one struct per file with a corresponding name. However, this proposal may face opposition from numerous developers, especially when it involves several small interdependent structs that aren't designed for individual usage. Alternatively, as you've also pointed out, putting together a custom build script could serve as a plausible option.

uncivil: Ok, got it now - my MacBook Pro didn't suck, I just had a virus scanner running on it. After removing the virus scanner, I reran my reservation service as a jar file again, and it now starts up even slightly faster than the main method start, in below 7 seconds compared to the 40 seconds before. Crazy stuff. I can imagine that virus scanners have a lot of work to do when a process unfolds/unpacks/looks into a file with many files in it. This is a huge efficiency killer, I have to say. So for anybody comin
civil:
Alright, I understand now. The decreased performance of my MacBook Pro wasn't due to the computer itself, but rather a result of having a virus scanner operating. After uninstalling the virus scanner and re-launching my reservation service as a jar file, the startup speed improved noticeably. It's quite interesting to note that it now starts up in under 7 seconds, an appreciable improvement from the previous 40 seconds.  
It's not hard to see that a virus scanner that diligently sifts through processes as they are unpacking would substantially reduce system efficiency. This could be a significant factor to consider for anyone looking to ensure optimal computer performance.

uncivil: @user i think there are some proposals floating around about functions whose signature changes in arbitrary ways based on the parameter types.   But what you're suggesting is far more extreme: you want the signature to change based on the values of the parameters.  Languages tend not to do this because it discourages abstraction: `x.addEventListener("messageEvent", ...)` works but `x.addEventListener(type, ...)` doesn't.  I've seen some academic compilers that try to handle this in various ways, but they
civil:
tend to generate code that is tough to understand, debug, and maintain.

Hello @user, there seem to be a few ideas circulating about adapting function signatures based on parameter types. Your concept, however, appears to be moving this boundary even further, suggesting variations in function signatures based on parameter values. This is not commonly seen in programming languages because it often discourages abstraction. For instance, while 'x.addEventListener("messageEvent", ...)' is proven to work, the more abstract 'x.addEventListener(type, ...)' does not. I have observed some academic compilers attempt to integrate this level of functionality, but they typically produce code that can be tricky to understand, debug, and upkeep.

uncivil: I'll review it. This should be a huge win.  Today we don't support `doc['field']`, leaving only `doc["field"]` and `doc.field`. We document/recommend `doc.field` only because double quote escaping such as `doc[\"field\"]` is hellacious. But `doc.field` is much slower.  Being able to support `doc['field']` gives us consistency with the script engines today, and it gives a 50% performance increase (we gave it more type information, removes dynamic lookup).
civil: I'll take a look at this. I believe this can usher in a significant victory. At this moment, we don't provide support for `doc['field']`, leaving us with only `doc["field"]` and `doc.field`. We recommend using `doc.field` primarily to avoid the complications that arise from double quote escaping like `doc[\"field\"]`. However, it's worth noting that `doc.field` tends to be quite slower. If we can accomplish supporting `doc['field']`, it would not only align us with the functionality of current script engines but incredibly boost our performance by 50% (as it provides more type information, eliminating dynamic lookup).

uncivil: Yeah - this mostly sucks, you're right - the root cause is that sync has to reset the database when done (I verified that when I started to trying to crash-proof this area), which means that really it should have exclusive database access while working. Even small touches (like reviews) while syncing might be rolled back. I suppose the proper course is really to open an issue that captures that idea - I'm list-based so if I don't log it I'll forget pretty quickly
civil: Yes, you're correct and I appreciate your perspective on this issue. The central challenge is that the synchronization process resets the database upon completion. This is something I confirmed when I began working on optimizing this area. Essentially, it means that while the sync is in operation, it should have exclusive database access. Even the slightest interference, such as responses, could be reversed if it occurs during that time. Ideally, we need to flag an issue to acknowledge this concern and aid its rectification. Speaking from a personal standpoint, I utilize lists for organization purposes, and hence, it's essential for me to document this down or it might slip my mind later.

However, when I started from scratch and rebuilt the container using this version, it didn't function as expected. I deeply appreciate your patience with this fluctuating information. civil: The mentioned scam incident carries a global scope and has been operational for more than a decade. As an Australian resident, I've been contacted several times, often by individuals with distinct accents. It's essential to remember that we cannot shield computer users from their own misguided actions. Believing that companies like ISPs or Microsoft would randomly reach out is a misconception. One effective method of dealing with such calls is to state your current busyness politely, request their contact details, and propose to revert at a more convenient time. Verification of bank accounts through small initial transfers is also another method to take into consideration.

uncivil: While I did mis-configure things, it was a very frustrating issue to run into that took awhile to track down. It's an easy configuration snafu to make and having the "am I registered" code behave one way and the registration code another is confusing. A node will successfully register with the trailing slash, then on the next pass through the registration loop it will register itself again because the status servlet doesn't find it.
civil: While it's certainly true that I mis-configured things, I found the issue quite challenging to resolve which was slightly frustrating. It's fairly simple to make such a configuration mishap, specifically when the functioning of the 'am I registered' code diverges from the registration code. This can be confusing as a node can smoothly register with the trailing slash but then in the subsequent registration cycle, it will register itself again due to the failure of the status servlet to locate it. This is an area that could perhaps be more intuitive.

Civil version: 

Pardon me for saying this, but I find it somewhat unusual to have Graylog rename fields for a backwards compatibility that is perhaps no longer necessary. The renaming process tends to create some confusion for me when it comes to parsing rules, and I've encountered this issue more than once. I generally have to refer back to the raw input or field value to clarify matters, as the Graylog web interface primarily displays the renamed value.

I see the rationale behind maintaining this status quo to ensure existing settings aren't inadvertently altered. It's comprehensible that new users might perceive this as unnecessary, but to my understanding, this is part of accommodating decisions made previously.

uncivil: I kinda doubt the libGDX devs will want to break compatibility for every single existing game for this. Unit tests, like the ones libGDX uses to test PRs, sometimes need to run on headless machines and don't have this as a valid option anyway. Invisible and silent unit tests also have a limited range of behavior they can actually detect; games often need a human being to point out that, say, too many zangulorgs are spawning in an area, or in a visually-obvious pattern, and not enough blanyayools spawn in
civil: I'm not entirely certain that the developers of libGDX would be eager to disrupt compatibility for all existing games to incorporate this suggestion. Keep in mind, unit tests, used frequently in libGDX's PR assessments, occasionally need to operate on headless machines rendering this proposition untenable. Furthermore, the scope of detection for unit tests that are both invisible and silent is somewhat restricted; games usually require human interaction to highlight certain issues, such as an excessive number of zangulorgs spawning in a certain area or visually obvious pattern, or the under-spawn of blanyayools.

uncivil: > BI applications will suffer greatly as businessbusers must have exact and not approximate results  Some additional thoughts about approaches for building user faith in numbers (dealing with fuzziness and the need for context):  As we move into BI a worry of mine is that search engines are not databases and they are designed to produce fuzzy sets (elements belong to the result set to varying degrees). In our search apps we frequently fail to explain to end users that the results can vary massively in mat
civil:
In regards to the use of BI applications, there can be significant challenges if they do not offer precise results to business users. To enhance the user experience, it's important to consider various strategies for building user trust in the numbers, particularly in relation to the inherent ambiguities associated with the use of these applications and providing the necessary context.

Moreover, as we venture into the world of BI, itâ€™s crucial to recognize that search engines and databases have different functionalities. Search engines are constructed to produce a range of results without necessarily pinpointing an exact response. Consequently, it is essential that users understand that the outputs generated can fluctuate considerably depending on the input query in our search applications.

It makes backporting other build changes, especially those that touch `BuildPlugin` a lot easier since this is a very large change.  The bummer with 7.x is that it still supports the JDK 8 runtime so there are a shit load of conditionals around runtime java version, which now is deferred until execution time. We can either solve this with the eventual goal to completely d
civil:
1. @user @user I've managed to backport changes to  `7.x`. This successfully accomplishes two things. 
   1. The configuration time bonus is now accessible in `7.x`. 
   2. This enables easier backporting of other build changes, particularly those that touch `BuildPlugin`, given the extensive nature of this change. 

One of the issues with 7.x is that it continues to support the JDK 8 runtime, which instigates numerous conditionals around the runtime Java version, now postponed until the execution time. The possible solution could involve a long-term plan to completely transition...

uncivil: ning. Avoiding Latin (and other languages that aren't English) keeps yet another language out of the mix. Expanding contractions avoids potential misreadings. Keeping the tense in the simple present avoids parsing of more than one tense.   Finally, many cultures expect a greater level of formality than native English speakers expect. If our audience were solely native English speakers, we could be a lot more "loose" in our writing. However, the Chinese (especially) and other asian cultures expect formal s
civil: 1. It may be beneficial to primarily use English in our discussions to avoid potential language confusion. Furthermore, fully spelling out contractions can help mitigate potential misunderstandings based on different interpretations. Also, using simple present tense might simplify the process of understanding our conversation. Let's be mindful that several cultures appreciate a more formal addressing style, notably in the Asian context where such etiquette is often expected. Having said that, if our audience comprised solely of native English speakers, there could be room for more informal interaction.

civil:
Let's go over some challenges we faced here. I'm here with my brother who works on Elasticsearch statistics, providing us with an excellent opportunity to test Nick's PR (https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/16817), especially since my brother is currently working on this. uncivil: authenticated token gets authenticated using the `CustomX509AuthenticationProvider`. However, when you switch to `authorizeHttpRequests` you are switching from `FilterSecurityInterceptor` to `AuthorizationFilter`, and the latter does not re-authenticate the request.  With that said I suggest that you put a breakpoint on the code I linked above to check the behavior described and you should revisit your custom filter implementation in order to validate the authentication token against the `AuthenticationMa
civil:
Thank you for your patience. Here is a bit of relevant information: an authenticated token tends to be authenticated using the `CustomX509AuthenticationProvider`. However, when you consider moving to `authorizeHttpRequests`, there's a transition from `FilterSecurityInterceptor` to `AuthorizationFilter`. You may observe here that the `AuthorizationFilter` does not conduct a re-authentication of the request. 

Therefore, to help understand and verify the outlined behavior, it might be instrumental to place a breakpoint on the specified code. Further, it could be beneficial to reassess your custom filter implementation. This would assist in validating the authentication token against the `AuthenticationManager`.

uncivil: This is an issue tracker, not a help center.  Next time you should really ask for help in the IRC channel or the forum.  I'm not trying to be a dick, I'll help you out since this is a simple question, but just keep this in mind.  You only need to dispose a `Shape` if you (or some third-party library) created it in Java code (i.e. with `new CircleShape()` or something).  If you call `fixture.getShape()`, you do NOT need to `dispose()` the resulting `Shape`; in fact, don't do so, you'll crash your game.  `S
civil:
Just so you're aware, this platform is primarily for tracking issues, whereas your query is more appropriate for support channels like the IRC channel or the forum. I don't mean any offense by this instruction, and I'm more than happy to assist you with this straightforward question. Just bear this in mind for future queries. 

In regards to your question, disposing of a `Shape` is only necessary if you, or a third-party library, created it using Java code such as `new CircleShape()`. If you use `fixture.getShape()`, there's no need to `dispose()` the `Shape`, in fact, doing so could possibly cause your game to crash. Hope this helps.

uncivil: Damn it's again the issue of the Java 1.8...  Had to add this: ```   compileOptions {         sourceCompatibility '1.8'         targetCompatibility '1.8'     } ```  This should be the default for new projects on the IDE...
civil:
It seems we are once again encountering an issue related to Java 1.8. To address this, I've added the following lines:

```   
compileOptions {
    sourceCompatibility '1.8'
    targetCompatibility '1.8'
}
```

Ideally, I believe this could be set as the default for new projects on the IDE to prevent similar issues in the future.

uncivil: I saw a couple sub-minute ones and on main it took 2'41", timeout for 5' should be adequate. I don't believe it's possible to do a retry on this one, the retry action I'm familiar with doesn't wrap actions only commands, and to do a retry on an action requires multiple attempts with status setting/checking (a real workflow monster with regard to code).  So just setting a timeout and failing faster, given current incidence of this one, seems like a good solution
civil: Upon reviewing, I observed a few instances where the actions were executed under a minute and one major execution that took 2'41". Considering these timings, a timeout for 5' might be appropriate. However, I'm little apprehensive about the possibility of a retry in this scenario. Based on my understanding, the retry function is typically used in tandem with commands, not actions, and attempting a retry on an action could necessitate multiple attempts while constantly setting and checking status; this situation could potentially create a complex workflow in the codes. Therefore, in the light of current recurrence of this instance, it seems a sensible solution to simply set a timeout and aim for a quicker failure response.

uncivil: Update:  I found a fix. Insert the following to ```./scripts/generate_bash_completion.sh```:  ```javabase=/sasdata/ra/user/john.doe/.loca/brew/opt/jdk```  where that path is in fact just ```JAVA_HOME```. This is certainly an ugly hack. If I am correct, setting ```--host_javabase``` and/or ```--javabase``` should achieve the same effect. However, I have no luck thus far. I tried to add the following to ```./BUILD```:  ``` java_runtime(     name =  "jdk_local",     java_home = "/sasdata/ra/user/john.doe/.lo
civil:
Update: I have come across a possible solution. Here's what you can try doing: 

Add this line to your ```./scripts/generate_bash_completion.sh``` file:

```javabase=/sasdata/ra/user/john.doe/.loca/brew/opt/jdk```

This path is simply a representation of the ```JAVA_HOME```. It might seem a bit crude but it's a way to get around.

In an ideal situation, setting ```--host_javabase``` and/or ```--javabase``` should have the desired outcome. Unfortunately, I haven't had success using those methods.

Additionally, you could try adding this to your ```./BUILD```:

``` java_runtime(     name =  "jdk_local",     java_home = "/sasdata/ra/user/john.doe/.loc```

Do let us know if this works for you.

civil:
@user, I'm the developer of AsyncHttpClient, which is a Netty-based HTTP client. I have developed keen interest in understanding what Android developers would use Netty for, specific protocol clients perhaps? Based on my experience with AsyncHttpClient, I noticed a minimal usage among Android users, causing me to consequently phase out support for both JDK6 and JDK7. With the adoption of JDK8, features like ConcurrentHashMap#computeIfAbsent became available to me.

From my point of view, Android vastly differs from standard Java, particularly in terms of API. For instance, Android SDK reminiscent of Java 7 lacks certain APIs, such as SSLParameters.html. I'd love to hear your thoughts on this.

uncivil: apted from {@link DirectFieldAccessor} to support convert Vavr collections to JDK collections because only they      * are supported in the base class ({@link AbstractNestablePropertyAccessor}) and the behaviour is hard to      * override/extend.      */     private static class VavrSupportingDirectFieldAccessor extends AbstractNestablePropertyAccessor {          private final Map<String, FieldPropertyHandler> fieldMap = new HashMap<>();          public VavrSupportingDirectFieldAccessor(Object object) {
civil:
The class VavrSupportingDirectFieldAccessor has been adapted from the DirectFieldAccessor to accommodate conversion from Vavr collections to JDK collections. This adaptation was considered necessary, given that only JDK collections are supported in the base class - the AbstractNestablePropertyAccessor, and this default behavior is quite challenging to override or extend. Consequently, the VavrSupportingDirectFieldAccessor characterized as a private static class extends AbstractNestablePropertyAccessor.

This class contains a fieldMap, which is a Map of strings and FieldPropertyHandlers that get initialized as a new HashMap. The VavrSupportingDirectFieldAccessor class is constructed with an object-type parameter.

uncivil: @user I think no. It does have an [`empty-lines`](https://yamllint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/rules.html#module-yamllint.rules.empty_lines) rule, but it only has a `max` option but we need a `min`. And we cannot limit it to all children of `steps:` without putting `# yamllint disable` and `# yamllint enable` around, which would look ugly.
civil: @user I respectfully disagree. While it's true that there is an [`empty-lines`](https://yamllint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/rules.html#module-yamllint.rules.empty_lines) rule, it only provides a `max` option. Unfortunately, we require a `min` option. Additionally, it seems we won't be able to limit this to all children of `steps:` unless we surround it with `# yamllint disable` and `# yamllint enable`, which could potentially impact the aesthetic of our work.

uncivil: network of has contact to Tor devs to get more background about the Tor issues. I saw that Tor connections are much slower and less reliable as they have been in the past. For BitcoinJ we could fall back to clear-net connections in the worst case (has some privacy issues). For the P2P network we don't have any alternative though.
civil: I've been in touch with Tor developers to gain further insights into the concerning issues with Tor. I've noticed that Tor connections have become significantly slower and less dependable compared to how they were before. Whilst we have the option of resorting to clear-net connections in extreme cases for BitcoinJ (despite certain privacy concerns), unfortunately, we have no available alternatives for the P2P network.

uncivil: e them. A `LinkedList` in Java is horrible! A two element `LinkedList` uses up exactly the same memory as a 10 element `ArrayList`. civil:
While using a `LinkedList` in Java might present some inefficiency issues, it's interesting to note that a two-element `LinkedList` requires the same memory allocation as a 10-element `ArrayList`. Even esteemed software engineer, Josh Bloch, prefers not to utilize it. 

As for the use of comparators and the possible switch to an `IntObjectMap`, my perspective remains doubtful regarding its effectiveness. From my observation, heavy memory usage from the current headers could be ascribed partially to the use of an `IntObjectMap`. Maybe adopting an `ObjectToObjectMap` could present a more memory-efficient approach.

uncivil: @user     public void uhOh() throws Exception {         HazelcastInstance hc = Hazelcast.getDefaultInstance();         HazelcastInstance hc2 = Hazelcast.newHazelcastInstance(hc.getConfig());          IList<Integer> list = hc.getList("list");         System.out.println("list should be 0, is " + list.size());         list.add(10);         System.out.println("list should be 1, is " + list.size());         list.destroy();         Thread.sleep(1000);         IList<Integer> otherlist = hc2.getList("list");
civil:
Hi @user,

I noticed the code you posted regarding the `uhOh()` function. It seems that you've created two instances of Hazelcast and are adding an integer to a list named 'list'. You're also printing out the sizes of the list before and after adding the number.

Then you chose to destroy the list and after some delay, tried to get the 'list' again from the second Hazelcast instance.

Here's your code:

```java
public void uhOh() throws Exception {         
    HazelcastInstance hc = Hazelcast.getDefaultInstance();         
    HazelcastInstance hc2 = Hazelcast.newHazelcastInstance(hc.getConfig());          
    IList<Integer> list = hc.getList("list");         
    System.out.println("list should be 0, is " + list.size());         
    list.add(10);         
    System.out.println("list should be 1, is " + list.size());         
    list.destroy();         
    Thread.sleep(1000);         
    IList<Integer> otherlist = hc2.getList("list");    
}
```

Is there a particular aspect of this code you're having trouble with or something specific you'd like feedback on?

1. I had a similar experience. The issue was that I was simply trying to install the 2.2.1 version through 'yum', without any extra steps. I just needed a basic `yum install ./elasticsearch-2.2.1.rpm`. However, when I attempted to start it, I encountered an issue saying, `CONF_FILE setting is no longer supported. elasticsearch.yml must be placed in the config directory and cannot be renamed.` 

The solution I found was in `/etc/sysconfig/elasticsearch`, where there was a `CONF_FILE=/etc/elasticsearch/elasticsearch.yml` line. Apparently, the RPM install process hadn't updated this. After a few minor...

uncivil: rg.apache.ignite.startup.cmdline.CommandLineStartup WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release CHECKPOINT_PARALLEL_SORT_THRESHOLD                              - [Integer] Starting from this number of dirty pages in checkpoint, array will be sorted with Arrays.parallelSort(Comparable[]) in case of CheckpointWriteOrder.SEQUENTIAL. CLIENT_THROTTLE_RECONNECT_RESET_TIMEOUT_INTERV
civil:
Attention please, rg.apache.ignite.startup.cmdline.CommandLineStartup has a slight warning. As a suggestion, you could use --illegal-access=warn to activate warnings for any upcoming illegal reflective access operations. Please do note that, for forthcoming versions, all illegal access operations will be denied. 

For your information, regarding CHECKPOINT_PARALLEL_SORT_THRESHOLD, when the number of dirty pages in checkpoint commences, from that particular number onward, the observed array will be sorted with Arrays.parallelSort(Comparable[]), if CheckpointWriteOrder is set to SEQUENTIAL. Also, please remember that the CLIENT_THROTTLE_RECONNECT_RESET_TIMEOUT_INTERVAL parameter is there for your use.

I must confess, the AnkiDroid data folder slipped my mind. Your reminder was very helpful, thank you. It appears some issue arose within the data folder, preventing AnkiDroid from functioning correctly. Here are the steps I've taken to rectify the situation: I uninstalled AnkiDroid, then proceeded to remove the AnkiDroid data folder and reboot the system. After that, I installed AnkiDroid again and it began working seamlessly. inally, I logged into the Anki server to synchronize my collections, and happily, everything is functioning normally again. My sincere gratitude for your assistance on this matter. It not only solved my problem but empowered me to troubleshoot effectively. Thank you!

Of course, following these steps will guide you to the successful compilation of your program:1. First, you'll need to open the command prompt.

2. Then, navigate to the folder containing your class files with this command: C:\>cd \mywork.3. The next step involves setting the path to include the JDKâ€™s binary files. For instance, you could use: C:\mywork> path c:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_25\bin%path%.4. Now, compile your class, or classes using the command: C:\mywork> javac *.java5. Your next task is to create a manifest file and the necessary jar file. Use the following commands:    C:\mywork> echo Main-Class: Craps >manifest.txt    C:\mywork> jar cvfm Craps.jar manifest.txt *.class or   C:\mywork> jar cvfe Craps.jar Craps *.class.6. Finally, it's time to test your jar file. Use either of these commands, depending on your configuration: C:\mywork> Craps.jar or C:\mywork> java -jar. I hope this helps! If you have any queries, please feel free to ask.

@user, if we're dealing with a particularly intricate graph (imagine three levels of contract/party/address), accounting for situations where the 'party' is null while still being able to aggregate any 'party' field might force us to create rather complex JSON for _source. In this instance, we would have to replace a blank 'party' with a 'party' object that has a null substitution. Moreover, each object type in 'party' would require its own null object with its own set of null values, and so on. Dealing with this could make applications that utilize _source a bit more challenging to handle. I have experienced this in a few cases, and I manage, but it's quite a process.

@user, it's important for us to recognize that there is a distinction between HTTP and the implementation of server socket. The server socket elements are particularly related to MCU specifics; a generic version would be inappropriate because these depend on both the MCU and the board it is incorporated into.HTTP, when we discuss aspects like parsing headers and bodies, will need to be incorporated within the client. For the ESP8266, I suggest starting here: http http. Please bear in mind, however, that this code is highly specific to a certain chip. For instance, it may not be beneficial to generate anything related to the 'espconn?*' content.

I would very much appreciate the opportunity to have a feature available when using Closure Compiler. This feature would mainly be designed to provoke an error if there are any attempts to instantiate an abstract or base type. I should mention that I'm not particularly concerned about abstract functions such as class methods in this scenario. Here's an example, written in JavaScript:``` js /**  * @user* @user */ ns.Fruit = function() { ... }  // Instantiating the base type Fruit would trigger a compiler error.var fruit = new ns.Fruit()/**  * @user * @user{ns.Fruit}
*/ ns.Banana = function() { ... }  // No compiler error when instantiating Banana, as it is not a base type.var banana = new ns.Banana() ```

plications. In any case, you cannot avoid having to think about it and you have to manage (maybe multiple) JDK installations on your machine. civil: Being able to manage your JAVA_HOME variable is integral, regardless of the number of JDK installations you might have on your machine. That being said, it is not necessarily connected to the existence of a JAVA_HOME variable. Many individuals employ their own unique approaches to manage their JDK installations. To give an example, on my Ubuntu operating system, I use the command 'sudo update-alternatives --config java' to switch between different JDKs and ensure I have the correct version path. An alternative method could be to place JAVA_HOME in my bashrc file to point it at the most recent JDK.

However, they > should put value in 25ms, 100ms, or 500ms latency variances, and about > those we are more confident. >  > All of this loops back to an underlying curiosity I had when readers asked > for latency numbers: how much value does latency truly give you versus > requests per second? Yes, in some frameworks' cases, the maximum may be a > li
civil:
Reflecting on the overall significance of the benchmarks, I'm uncertain if many individuals would place a substantial amount of decision-making importance on latency variances of 0.1 to 0.5ms. However, latency variances of 25ms, 100ms, or 500ms certainly carry a significant weight and it is with these measurements that our confidence is higher.

This leads me back to a question I initially posed when readers inquired about latency numbers: how does latency compare in value to requests per second? In some frameworks' instances, the maximum could prove consequential.

uncivil: lar - not so fancy - use case: We use the ES 5.x client in the code for a Storm topology. The Storm distribution packs log4j2 2.1 -  which is on the class path of all Storm processes on the cluster. ES client is not content with that version due to some new log4j2 API changes I guess so what are the options:  - replace all log4j2 2.1 jars on the Storm cluster with 2.7 - attempt to roll a shaded *.jar which packs log4j2 2.7 with relocation of `org.apache.logging.log4j`moved to different location, `META-INF
civil:
We are currently utilizing the ES 5.x client within our Storm topology programming. The Storm distribution includes log4j2 2.1, which is an integral element of all Storm processes throughout the cluster. It appears that the ES client may not be compatible with this version, possibly due to updates in log4j2 API. Given these circumstances, we are exploring what our potential solutions might be, namely:

- The option of replacing all instances of log4j2 2.1 jars across the Storm cluster with the version 2.7
- Alternatively, we are considering creating a shaded *.jar that comprises log4j2 2.7, with `org.apache.logging.log4j` subsequently relocated to a different location, i.e., `META-INF. 

Would this be a feasible solution for us?

uncivil: Here comes the reproducer (sort of, not necessarily tomcat specific): http Note that the underscores in filenames are directory separators.  When calling `GET http (served by tomcats DefaultServlet, important: call it without a cached version!) or `GET http you won't see any CSP response header.
civil: Here we can observe the duplicator, regardless of it being particularly associated with Tomcat or not: http. The underscores seen in filenames are operating as directory separators. When making a `GET http request (which is handled by Tomcat's DefaultServlet), it's crucial to note that it should be done without any pre-existing cached versions. If you proceed with the `GET http request, you will find that no CSP response headers are present.

civil: I can understand your sense of frustration. However, referring to it as "Banging my head bloody" might not be the most effective way to initiate a bug report. In most cases, queries like these might be better addressed on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com) first, before presenting an issue here. uncivil: Anything "new SQL stuff" which contains named parameters like `NULL`, `ON` or other keywords can easily create trouble for the parser. For example: `NULL` is usually a value expression, but for `JSON_ARRAY` it suddenly became something completely different.  Which means, we need to teach JSQLParser to check first if the `NULL` is suddenly part of the `JSON_ARRAY` function before we can accept it as value expression.  (Irrelevant side note: There is a reason why I complained about syntax like `JSON_ARRAY(N
civil: It's noteworthy that certain "new SQL elements" that carry named parameters such as `NULL`, `ON`, or other keywords may bring about some complications for the parser. Case in point, `NULL` is typically identified as a value expression, but within `JSON_ARRAY`, it assumes a completely unexpected role. Therefore, it's a requirement to instruct JSQLParser to initially verify if `NULL` is integrated into the `JSON_ARRAY` function prior to giving clearance as a value expression. Incidentally, I must mention, there's a justifiable rationale behind my earlier concerns regarding syntax like `JSON_ARRAY(N.

uncivil: On test-servers this works pretty well in combination with Filebeat and its Elasticsearch-module as we do not have that much traffic there - BUT on our current productive system Filebeat cannot keep up with the mass of auditlogs Elasticsearch is writing. Our ELK then was ddosing itself with logs (Java logs like: `Caused by: java.io.IOException: No space left on device` + the dozens of Java log-lines such logs create) after the system thought there is not enough space left as we hit this http  This gets th
civil: In testing servers, there seems to be a seamless interaction between Filebeat and its Elasticsearch-module, probably due to the less traffic present. However, in our live productive system, Filebeat appears to struggle with the volume of auditlogs produced by Elasticsearch. This has resulted in our ELK inadvertently overwhelming itself with logs, as evidenced by Java logs displaying the message `Caused by: java.io.IOException: No space left on device`, alongside numerous other Java log-lines. This occurred when the system believed there was insufficient storage remaining, triggering an error over HTTP.

uncivil: @user First, thanks for trying to get K-9 Mail to work with PGP/MIME encrypted/signed messages!  However, I don't think this is the right approach. This pull request doesn't address the core problem that prevents us from having proper PGP/MIME support. It's the fact that K-9 Mail doesn't store messages in a way that allows reconstructing byte-identical copies of the original message. Worse, we can't even retrieve the structure of the original MIME tree. This pull request contains a lot of very nasty hacks
civil: @user Firstly, I must express my gratitude for your effort in attempting to make K-9 Mail compatible with PGP/MIME encrypted/signed messages. Although your efforts are commendable, I hope you understand that this may not be the right approach to the problem. The current pull request does not adequately address the fundamental problem inhibiting proper PGP/MIME support. This lies in the fact that K-9 Mail does not preserve messages in a manner that would allow for the recompilation of byte-identical copies of the initial message. Unfortunately, we can't even access the structure of the original MIME tree. I think this pull request consists of several problematic workarounds - can we look into refining it together?

uncivil: ``` I strongly recommend to mention Acoustic Echo Cancellation in the wiki or the docs. Reason: Echo AVOIDING is always better than Echo Cancellation. No matter how good the algorithm in Flash might be it cannot beat a session, where there is no acoustic echo in the first place. Like when everybody is on headsets. The often used practice "everybody not talking mutes his mic" is helpful but can generate some nasty audio artifacts when a mic is unmuted. I am more than happy to explain why, but think most pe
civil: I kindly suggest considering the inclusion of Acoustic Echo Cancellation in the wiki or the documentation. I believe that echo prevention can be a more effective strategy than echo cancellation. Despite the excellence of the Flash algorithm, its performance may not compare to a session that originally doesn't have any acoustic echo, like in situations where everyone uses headsets. The common practice of muting microphones when not in use can be beneficial, however, it can sometimes result in undesirable audio artifacts when a mic is unmuted. I would be glad to provide more information on this matter, but I assume most people understand the concept.

uncivil: @user I don't think using `final String topic = topicName;` is a good idea. IIRC sink can use multiple input topics (via `--inputs`) and we'd want to route them to appropriate destinations. "_" appear as result of replacement of ":" and "/" in the full topic name (URI as in "persistent://tenant/ns/topic") that snowflake connector does internally to generate table name compatible with the snowflake. Theoretically, topic2table mapping of `"persistent___tenant_ns_topic:cooltablename"` might work though it di
civil: @user, with all due respect, I'd like to express a minor concern regarding the use of `final String topic = topicName`. My understanding is that sink can actually accommodate multiple input topics (via `--inputs`), thus routing them to the respective destinations. The symbol "_" usually appears as a result of replacing ":" and "/" in the full topic name (URI like "persistent://tenant/ns/topic") which the snowflake connector internally executes to generate a table name compatible with the snowflake. Hypothetically, a topic2table mapping of `"persistent___tenant_ns_topic:cooltablename"` might actually function, though it's not entirely certain.

ight. - Futhermore, it's likely we can put some of these checks off until a later phase if needed so why wouldn't we want to avoid unnecessary checks?

uncivil: As stated a several times, its the nature of the beast. And so many different factors can contribute to the lower response on TechEmpowered.  Hardware:  Your CPU core are newer with a higher base speed so it can push more instructions per core.  The 40 (  40 + 40 HT ) Core server they use is a multi socket system and multi socket also introduces latency with inner communication. Add to this servers tend to run FB-DIMM what is different beast then your Unbuffered-Dimms.   Hell, maybe your CPU is using SSL
civil:
As I have mentioned on a few occasions, the inherent characteristics of the system can largely affect the lower response on TechEmpowered. Numerous factors can play into this.

Let's talk about hardware for a moment. Your CPU core is relatively modern and features a higher base speed. Consequently, it has the capacity to execute more instructions per core. The server they use, a 40 core system (including 40 HT), is a multi socket setup. This type of system can possibly introduce latency issues due to internal communication. Moreover, servers typically run on FB-DIMM, which performs differently than your Unbuffered-Dimms.

An additional point to consider is that your CPU may be using SSL, which can also impact their performance.

uncivil: long incubation period. In fact, I think Elasticsearch has done a pretty good job of staying ahead of the pace here. We made the decision to baseline Elasticsearch 8.0 on Java 17 shortly after it went GA and we have [an open PR](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/90571) to bump the bundled runtime to Java 19 already as well.  So I don't think there's any fundamental reluctance to taking advantage of new language and runtime features. The difference here is that historically we've at least wait
civil: The rather extended anticipation period aside, Elasticsearch seems to have performed quite admirably in terms of keeping up with advancements. After the general availability announcement, we swiftly made the decision to base Elasticsearch 8.0 on Java 17 and, there is currently a proposal under consideration to upgrade the default runtime to Java 19. So, it seems that there isn't an inherent hesitation in implementing new language and runtime additions. The minor contrast here is that we've traditionally preferred to wait.

uncivil: > HTTP tunnel is an obvious and horrible security hole. Taking into consideration that MySQL user passwords are often not very secured, never change, etc.  You always can hide your script by using random chars in path and nobody except you will not know path. And you still need to know DB login and pass. Also .htaccess with IP grants still actual. Not a problem. Also nobody will use this way if normal SSH access present. But sometimes you have no way and must use it
civil: HTTP tunneling does present potential security concerns, particularly considering the frequency at which MySQL user passwords can be insecure or unchanged for extended lengths of time. A potential workaround could involve hiding your script using random characters in the path. However, keep in mind that the database's login and password will still need to be secure, and using .htaccess with IP grants can certainly help maintain security. Utilizing HTTP tunneling is not typically the first choice if SSH access is readily available, but occasionally it may be the only option available depending on the specific circumstances.
