civil: @user Thank you for sharing your thoughts. To my understanding, the `additionalQueryString` does add value to our dashboard message tables. uncivil: ow better where to look...? There has to be another problem related to a case when it can't write all at once, when I proxied 300 local bots, there was no more $Entries than 200 in total. To manage read() calls without autoread(which would make things even worse), I depend on a following behaviour:  <s>[some packets waiting in the queue] <s>flush a batch of packets ->  ```     handle.write(Unpooled.EMPTY_BUFFER, promise );     handle.flush(); ```  <s>(while the promise, when finished, will call read() on
civil:
Do you know where exactly we might look into this? There seems to be an additional issue related to a situation where it can't write everything simultaneously. For instance, when I proxied over 300 local bots, the total number of $Entries did not exceed 200. My system operates in a specific way, relying on read() calls whilst avoiding autoread (which might potentially aggravate the situation). Here's how I typically deal with it:

1. Packets get queued up.
2. I flush a group of packets by implementing:

```
handle.write(Unpooled.EMPTY_BUFFER, promise);
handle.flush();
```
3. In the end, the promise, once it's completed, will trigger a read() command.

uncivil: I couldn't determine from the logs, if it is indeed the case, but could it be related to IPv6 and #1937 ?  T-Mobile US has moved over to using IPv6 on its 4G networks and TextSecure / Android does not correctly handle this case.  If this is the issue, there appear to be two (ugly) workarounds. 1) Disable WiFi before sending the MMS. 2) Disable IPv6 on your APN.
civil:
Upon reviewing the logs, I wasn't able to definitively conclude whether the issue at hand may be related to IPv6 and #1937. However, it's possible that it could be linked. As you may be aware, T-Mobile US has shifted to utilizing IPv6 on its 4G networks, and it appears that TextSecure/Android may not be handling this transition seamlessly. 

If this is the root cause of the problem, it seems we may have a couple of workarounds, despite them not being the most elegant solutions. The first possible solution might be to disable WiFi before attempting to send any MMS. The second alternative could involve disabling IPv6 on your APN settings. Please let me know if these suggestions seem feasible or if further clarification is needed!

uncivil: It looks like that page is describing goals and problems with 3.x. In my reading, this statement was meant to apply to 3.x:  > UGLY: The upstream events triggered as a side effect of a downstream event is triggered by the caller thread,  AFAIK upstream (inbound) events are the ones we are handling in our handler, could it be that a "side effect of a downstream event" could involve our handler's callbacks getting called by an unexpected thread when some outgoing data fails to send, or when the connection i
civil:
From my perspective, this particular page seems to be elaborating the objectives and challenges associated with 3.x. On scanning over it, it appears to me that the following statement may be specifically referring to 3.x: 

> UGLY: The upstream events triggered as a result of a downstream event is instigated by the calling thread.

To my knowledge, when discussing upstream (or inbound) events, these are usually the matters we are addressing within our handler. It raises a question; could it be a possibility that "side effect of a downstream event" may implicitly mean our handler's callbacks could be activated by an unforeseen thread; for instance, when there is a difficulty in transmitting some outgoing data, or when the connection is unexpectedly interrupted?

uncivil: e are so quick that the random sampling may miss specific outlier > requests that cause the "sniff check" (divide total execution time by > number of requests completed to determine average latency) to fail. >  > For our purposes, I feel in the short-term we can just include messaging > that explains the latency data is a sampling of random requests and may be > especially inaccurate for high-performance frameworks due to the small > number of samples taken. >  > I don't feel that takes away tremendously
civil:
from the overall usefulness of the data. While some specific outlier requests might be overlooked due to the rapid rate of our sampling method, it nevertheless allows us to estimate the average latency. For the time being, we could simply inform readers that our latency data is based on a random selection of requests and its accuracy might vary for high-performance frameworks because of the limited number of samples considered.

I firmly believe that this minor limitation doesn't significantly diminish the overall value of the data presented.

uncivil: Library/Frameworks//CoreFoundation.framework/CoreFoundation.tbd and library file /System/Library/Frameworks//CoreFoundation.framework/CoreFoundation are out of sync. Falling back to library file for linking.   JAVA_HOME        : /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-10.0.1.jdk/Contents/Home Java library path: $(JAVA_HOME)/lib/server JNI cpp flags    : -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include/darwin JNI linker flags : -L$(JAVA_HOME)/lib/server -ljvm Updating Java configuration in /Library/Frameworks/R
civil:
It appears that the files Library/Frameworks//CoreFoundation.framework/CoreFoundation.tbd and /System/Library/Frameworks//CoreFoundation.framework/CoreFoundation are not in perfect alignment at the moment. Consequently, the library file will be utilized for any linkage processes. 

In regards to your Java configuration, JAVA_HOME is currently set to /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-10.0.1.jdk/Contents/Home. For your reference, we use this as the Java library path: $(JAVA_HOME)/lib/server. Furthermore, the JNI cpp flags are currently -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include -I$(JAVA_HOME)/include/darwin and the JNI linker flags are -L$(JAVA_HOME)/lib/server -ljvm. All of this has been or will be updated in the Java configuration in /Library/Frameworks/R.

uncivil: This needs to be fixed. The very common scenario faced as an a user, signal is my default text app. I have evangelized to several iphone friends to install signal for whatever reason signal notifications are not enabled on their iPhone. My choices are to remember to switch to insecure before EVERY send, or feel like an idiot requesting that they turn on signal notifications or uninstall and deregister the app I just asked them to install.  This is terrible and until fixed I will never ask anyone to instal
civil:
I would like to bring up something that needs addressing, which occurs quite frequently in my experience as a user. Signal happens to be my default texting application and I have successfully recommended it to several of my iPhone-user friends. However, it seems that Signal notifications are not automatically enabled on their iOS devices. 

My options seem to be: reminding myself to switch to unsecured sending before each message, which isn't really practical; or asking them to enable Signal notifications, which could be inconvenient. Alternatively, I could suggest they uninstall and deregister the app, which defeats the purpose of recommending it in the first place. 

This predicament is less than ideal, and until there's some resolution, I would hesitate to suggest anyone else install Signal.

uncivil: So the fix is to replace that `for()` loop (ugh!) with `sapply()`:  ```r pkgs.version <- sapply(seq_along(pkgs.name), function(i){         .rs.packageVersion(pkgs.name[[i]], pkgs.library[[i]], instPkgs)       }) ```  And now the `check.rows=FALSE` is no longer necessary, so I reverted that.
civil:
It seems the issue can potentially be resolved by substitifying the `for()` loop with `sapply()`. Here is an alternative approach:

```r
pkgs.version <- sapply(seq_along(pkgs.name), function(i){         
    .rs.packageVersion(pkgs.name[[i]], pkgs.library[[i]], instPkgs)       
})
``` 

Having incorporated this change, it doesn't appear that `check.rows=FALSE` is needed anymore, so I've taken the liberty of reverting it.

civil: In my personal view, I can appreciate the expectation for a 'null' result, especially in situations where there may not be a match through the filters. However, given the operational framework of the default mode, this may not realistically apply. As @user subtly mentioned earlier, even considering making the 'default' mode min/max aggregators return '0' would likely necessitate the storage of extra information to distinguish inactive aggregating values. This could potentially mean rethinking the usage of primitive numeric base aggregators or consistently employing the nullable version and simply converting to 0.

civil: Sometimes it might be necessary to use `["-Wl,--start-group", some_label, some_other_label, "-Wl,--end-group"]` if there are some confusion with interdependencies in the existing code. I'm curious if this is the motivation behind supporting (albeit imperfectly) labels in `linkopts`. An alternative solution could be to use a `genrule` or similar to combine the static libraries, subsequently incorporating the resultant object into `srcs`. However, it's worth noting this solution may have certain limitations in a context where there are multiples platforms and various toolchains, including 'c'.

uncivil: really should never make it out the door   There's no JAR hell check to prevent `gradle assemble` from succeeding, though, so it was easy for me to have this fail.  I think the problem I experience is this:  * As a developer, I can build a plugin successfully that would fail jar-hell check. * As a user, I can install a plugin that would fail jar-hell check.  Proposal: Can we add a gradle check for this "jar hell" thing? This would prevent a plugin from being shipped at all if it fails this check. Impact:
civil: I have recently experienced a particular issue which leads me to propose a suggestion. The situation at hand is related to the absence of a JAR hell check as a part of the `gradle assemble` process. This lack of a safety net allowed me to build a plugin that would ordinarily fail said check. Furthermore, as a user, one could also install a plugin that would not pass the JAR hell check. Therefore, I would like to propose the inclusion of a gradle check for JAR hell prior to the dispatch of a plugin. This measure would help to rectify any potential issues beforehand, preventing the shipment of a plugin that would ultimately fail this check. Please consider the potential impact of this proposal.

uncivil: act take out all the BitShares derivatives, it's a total scam.  Are you starting to see my point?  Just because a coin is on a major exchange and people trade it in volume doesn't make it any better or worse than any other. People are sheep and they don't investigate the code, the backers, the internet reports or the security aspects. And then they will scream blue murder when someone takes their money.  It comes down to this: Do we want to _look_ legitimate by acting as a pseudo-government "nanny" and tr
civil:
ansparently banning those we think might harm others? Or do we want to be legitimate and provide tools to every one capable of making their own decisions? 

We should consider removing BitShares derivatives from our portfolio. Just consider my perspective for a moment - the legitimacy of a currency does not solely hinge upon its presence on major exchanges or its trading volume. It's essential that we encourage a culture of due diligence where individuals actually investigate the code, examine the backers, read the internet reports, and thoroughly consider the security aspects. For if we don't do so, these unsuspecting individuals might fall prey to unscrupulous activities. Eventually, the question we need to ask ourselves is: Do we merely want to appear responsible by playing the role of a pseudo-government and ban what we consider might potentially harm others? Or do we genuinely want to nurture a sense of responsibility by providing appropriate tools to every individual, leaving the decision-making in their own capable hands?

uncivil: We need to change all definitions those interpret `0` as infinite or `Integer.MAX_VALUE` to make configuration consistent across all modules, not only for `QueueConfig`.    There are many of them; max-size of map, list, multimap; ttl, max-idle, queue-size of job-tracker etc. Also these are defined in XSD too, not only config classes.   Otherwise this will introduce a greater WTF.
civil: I believe we should reconsider all definitions that interpret `0` as infinite or `Integer.MAX_VALUE` for the sake of consistency across all our modules, not just within `QueueConfig`. Many of these definitions - such as max-size for maps, lists, and multimaps, as well as ttl, max-idle, and queue-size for job-tracker - also exist within the XSD, not just within the configuration classes. If we fail to address this issue, it could potentially lead to greater confusion and complications down the line.

uncivil: When contemplating schema+data version it's possible there are multiple changes in each version, and if done right each change would be in a transaction, would be separate and would be tolerant of failure. They may not be idempotent though, so if you do 2.9.0-migration1 but OOM on 2.9.0-migration2 (or something), you haven't setAnkiDroidVersion(2.9.0) yet (as proposed above) and you'd re-try 2.9.0-migration1. For that reason all the migration tools I've used or written treat migrations as a list of change
civil: When we consider schema and data versioning, it's quite possible that each version includes multiple changes. Ideally, each change would be executed in a separate transaction and be capable of withstanding failure. The one caveat is that these operations may not be idempotent, meaning that if a failure occurs during say, 2.9.0-migration2, you wouldn't have yet set the AnkiDroidVersion to 2.9.0 as suggested earlier. Consequently, you'd have to repeat 2.9.0-migration1. That's why any migration tools I've interacted with or developed treat migrations as a sequential list of changes.

uncivil: eed cleaned all up and balance was also confirmed with importing the seeds in electrum (one need to make 2 wallets there, one for legacy and one for segwit - and BSQ has to be considered as well).   I highly recommend to NOT use Electrum for sending out funds (for cross checking the balance its ok) as specially with BSQ things can go very wrong (BSQ burned) and if Bisq app is still in use Bisq data can get screwed up. Also getting out funds vai Bisq always works (at least I have not seen any case so far w
civil:
It appears that your recent activities involved cleaning up your account and balancing of imported seeds in Electrum, which is great. I noticed that you had to create two wallets, one for legacy and the other for SegWit- please don't forget to consider BSQ as important as well. 

Having said that, I would strongly suggest refraining from using Electrum, especially for sending out funds. Although it is quite a handy tool for cross-checking the balances, there seems to be certain downsides. Particularly with BSQ transactions, there are higher risks involved. There have been instances where BSQ gets unintentionally burned, which is not ideal. Also, if the Bisq app is still in use, the data can experience some disturbances. 

It's worth mentioning, however, that transferring funds out via Bisq generally seems to be consistently successful. I am yet to come across any issues in periods of its usage. I hope this information is helpful for you!

civil:
This programming code appears to be facing a potential issue. When 'count' is greater than 'utflen', it's producing a UTFDataFormatException, stating that there's a partial character at the end of the inputs. This points to a malformed input. 

Furthermore, the variables 'char2' and 'char3' are set to specific bytes within the data, but there seems to be another problem here. If char2 or char3 don't meet certain specifications - that is, char2 and char3 taken bitwise AND 0xC0 not equal to 0x80 - another UTFDataFormatException error is thrown. This points to a malformed input found around the specific byte value of count minus one. 

Therefore, there's a need to ensure that consistent and well-formed input values are passed in, so as to prevent these issues. I recommend a careful review of the data inputs to alleviate these error messages.

uncivil: ]: ``` [2021-08-05T21:40:38,643][ERROR][o.e.b.ElasticsearchUncaughtExceptionHandler] [maclastic.local] uncaught exception in thread [main] org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.StartupException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: failed to load plugin x-pack-sql due to jar hell         at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.Elasticsearch.init(Elasticsearch.java:171) ~[elasticsearch-8.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.0.0-SNAPSHOT]         at org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.Elasticsearch.execute(Elasticsearch.java:158) ~[elasticsearch-8.0.0-SNA
civil:
This comment appears to be reporting a problem in a system log related to Elasticsearch, a searchable database system. In attempting to load the plugin named `x-pack-sql`, an `IllegalStateException` was generated in response to an occurrence known as 'jar hell'. This usually happens when conflicting versions of the same Java Archive (JAR) files are detected by the system. 

The stack trace appears to pinpoint the issue to Elasticsearch's initialization (Elasticsearch.init) and execution phases (Elasticsearch.execute). Having occurred in the main thread, and without a specific exception handling process in place, the issue resulted in an `UncaughtExceptionHandler`. This is a mechanism that can help in catching and handling uncaught exceptions, but in this case, the thread failed to recover from the exception.

Kindly inquire if a more detailed exploration is needed or if further explanation on certain components of this output is required.

civil: E uses minimal RAM. Thus, when any of these files undergoes a change, it is detected, but Bazel can't specify which one. Truthfully, I am unsure about the mechanism we employ to detect changes in the input files. To rectify this situation, we could consider two options: 1. Avail ourselves of Skyframe invalidation - this might not be functional on Bazel server restarts, but should suffice in most instances, despite its complexity, 2. Substitute the action cache - it seems to be increasingly attractive, serving multiple purposes, but it is not just a trivial task.

uncivil: y did the "every operator has to ensure it is closed" thing. It was a complex mess. (We didn't have `Sequence` to help.) Then Drill let it's fragment runner do the work. The code became much simpler and resource leaks disappeared, even in nasty error situations.  The operator prototype learned from Drill's experience. The operator "DAG" is managed by a fragment runner which knows of every operator in the DAG, and which ensures that, come hell or high water, the operators are closed. The result is that the
civil:
operator handling process has improved significantly.

Could you clarify why every operator has to ensure it is closed? Initially, the task seemed quite complicated without the assistance of `Sequence`. However, Drill delegated this task to its fragment runner leading to a significant simplification of the code and eliminating resource leaks, even in complex error situations.

It appears the operator prototype took valuable lessons from Drill's implementation. The operator "DAG" is managed by a fragment runner, which is aware of every operator within the DAG and diligently ensures all operators are closed regardless of potential obstacles or difficulties. Consequently, the operation process has become significantly more efficient.

uncivil: Also: http  What and end user thinks of 'external storage' is better named 'removable storage'.  And for Android 4.4 the problem is (again quoting):  "... apps cannot write to or otherwise modify such removable storage. Note that device manufacturers themselves may have ways of dealing with this, but ordinary app developers do not."  For Android 5.0 there is a solution documented here:  http  We need to implement this if we want to support SD card support.  This also does need careful design as we probab
civil:
In addition, I was reading through an interesting article and thought it was worthwhile discussing the topic with you all. The term 'external storage' typically holds a different implication for end users, for whom, 'removable storage' seems to be a more fitting term. This brings to light a certain issue with Android 4.4. As stated in the article, "Applications are unable to write to or make alterations to such removable storage." This limitation does not extend to device manufacturers who possibly have their methods to address it, leaving app developers in a challenging situation.

For Android 5.0, the article provides a solution for this matter. If we're considering adding SD card support, it would be prudent to implement the solution. Furthermore, careful design indeed becomes imperative, as the scenario is probably more nuanced than we initially envisaged. I thought this might be a topic worthy of further exploration.

civil: I would like to clarify that the topic elaborated in Nejmeh's Article, specifically issue #146 seems to be not connected to our current discussion. It is merely my personal viewpoint that the author of the issue might have made an incorrect assumption in proposing that a check should analyze code blocks and ascertain if there is an exit point. uncivil: Dude it's not hard. When you get the error, click the Share button. If you have the option, select Copy to clipboard / or / Open in Notes. So you can then select the text and copy it from there, open http Paste the copied text in "**Paste the JSON bugreport here**". Click _Transform_. And click Copy to clipboard. Then paste it here as a comment or edit your issue and paste the report there.  Or simply wait for #3579 to be merged and released :/
civil:
I understand that this process may seem a little complicated at first, but it's actually quite straightforward. Here's a gentle guide to help you:

When you encounter the error, please click on the 'Share' button. If it's available to you, you could choose either 'Copy to clipboard' or 'Open in Notes'. This allows you to then highlight and copy the text.

After doing so, you need to open the following link: http. Once there, please paste the copied text in the field marked "**Paste the JSON bug report here**". Then proceed to click on '_Transform_'. Now, you can click on 'Copy to clipboard'. 

You're doing great. Now, you can paste your copied text here as a comment, or go ahead and edit your issue to insert the report there. If all else fails, you could also opt to wait for #3579 to be merged and released, whichever you find most convenient. I hope this clarifies things for you!

uncivil: Cool, if you thought about all the things then OK. I don't have much skin in this particular game anyway, as I haven't used Box2d in the past decade or so.  > Assuming values in libGDX that should be provided by Box2D couples both libraries in a fragile way.  FWIW, we could set the defaults from Java rather than rely on whatever Box2d uses for defaults.  > If we return the Fixture's Filter instance to the user and modifies it, it is causing an inconsistency between internal/native Box2D and Java states.
civil:
I appreciate your comprehensive thoughts on the matter. I admit, I may not be as deeply involved in this as I have not utilized Box2D in some time, spanning about a decade. 

Just a thought - it's plausible that having libGDX's values dependent on Box2D interconnects the two libraries in a somewhat precarious way. However, we could possibly initialize the default settings from Java, eliminating the need to lean on Box2D's default configurations. 

Do consider this - if we exposed the Fixture's Filter instance to the user, allowing their modifications, it may generate incongruity between the states of Box2D and Java.

uncivil: It turned out that: - there is a lot of places using static-context logging - manual already mentions this problem  I limited work on this issue to: - switching static-context logging to node-based logging wherever possible - fixing logger static-context init section to invoke it as early as possible - fixing logger static-context init section to take custom factory under consideration (a bug before)  Recommendations: - User node-based logger wherever possible - Logger.getLogger() can be used in special c
civil:
Upon reviewing the situation, it was discovered that static-context logging is utilized in several places. Interestingly, the manual has already highlighted this particular issue. Given these circumstances, my focus for this issue was predominately limited to the following areas:

1. I worked on shifting from static-context logging to node-based logging as much as possible.
2. I endeavored to amend the logger's static-context initialization section to ensure it was invoked as early as possible.
3. I also worked on adjusting the logger's static-context initialization section to take custom factories into account, as this had previously been overlooked and was causing a bug.

Recommendations moving forward:

1. It is advisable to switch to node-based logger whenever feasible.
2. In exceptional circumstances, Logger.getLogger() may be utilized.

civil:
Dear @user, 

Please note a few changes I've noticed in the code from lines 581 to 583, and onwards.

Instead of calling the error, it's caught within an IOException e. In the case where logger.isWarnEnabled becomes active, the logger warns with the error messgae "Error while closing a pipe", and this is followed by the parameter e.

Also, in the update, I see the inclusion of a new function called safeShutdownPipe. This function, which accepts int pipe as a parameter, is designed to close the pipe safely only when the pipe value isn't -1. Looking for your feedback and confirmation on these updates. Thanks.

civil: I'm unable to find any issues or bugs pertaining to 'SpawnModules' class stopping the progression to beta1. Now grab the APK cd tmpfs && cp system/priv-app/DocumentsUIGoogle/DocumentsUIGoogle.apk <<Destination?>> 5. Download it to your phone (how you do that is your choice... I've used ncat on the phone, which seems
civil:
1. Kindly remove the AP(.tar) from a compressed archive, which is usually the case.
2. It would be great if you could extract it using this: (tar -xvz AP.tar system.img.lz4 && lz4 -d system.img.lz4 && simg2img system.img out.img)
3. Please proceed with mounting: create a new directory (mkdir tmpfs), then mount it (mount -o loop out.img tmpfs). You should now be able to see a mount point in that directory, which should ideally be empty.
4. Now, kindly locate the APK by changing your directory (cd tmpfs) and copying it (cp system/priv-app/DocumentsUIGoogle/DocumentsUIGoogle.apk <<Destination?>>)
5. Please download it to your phone however you find it most convenient. Personally, I've used ncat on the phone and found it to be quite user-friendly.

uncivil: > I've tried a similar scenario and the problems seems to lie with Bisq.  Yes, this seems to be the case, as the transfer went fine.   Feedback from this experience indicate the following:  - there is no need to specify receiver's city, just country - there should be no need to specify currency in the payment account, since the whole point of Western Union is to work internationally regardless of currency   - exception: countries with currencies in which Western Union has no presence in (a list should be
civil:
provided for reference)

1. Based on my experience with a similar situation, it appears the issue might stem from Bisq. Interestingly though, the transfer seemed to execute without any trouble. From this experience, I've gathered a few suggestions:

   - Perhaps this service could operate without needing to specify the receiver's city, only the country.
 
   - It might also be beneficial to remove the requirement for specifying currency in the payment account, as Western Union generally functions without regard to currency due to its international nature.
   
   - An exception could be made for countries whose currencies are not supported by Western Union. Providing a list of these countries would be handy for reference.

uncivil: mark.fatJar142             avgt   10  18.972 Â± 0.264   s/op MinimalBenchmark.explodedJarMain            avgt   10   1.984 Â± 0.098   s/op MinimalBenchmark.fatJar                     avgt   10  11.982 Â± 0.471   s/op PetclinicBenchmark.devtoolsRestart          avgt   10   1.605 Â± 0.193   s/op PetclinicBenchmark.explodedJarMain          avgt   10   5.791 Â± 0.460   s/op PetclinicBenchmark.fatJar                   avgt   10  36.068 Â± 0.585   s/op PetclinicBenchmark.noverify                 avgt   10  31.803 Â± 0
civil:
"Here are some results from some benchmarks we've conducted: 

1. For mark.fatJar142, the average time came out to 18.972 seconds with a small variance of 0.264 s/op. 

2. For MinimalBenchmark.explodedJarMain, the average was significantly lower at 1.984 seconds with a variance of 0.098 s/op. 

3. For MinimalBenchmark.fatJar, the average time was larger at 11.982 seconds, and had a standard deviation of 0.471 s/op. 

4. Turning to the PetclinicBenchmark, the average time for devtoolsRestart was quite low at 1.605 seconds with a variance of 0.193 s/op. 

5. For PetclinicBenchmark.explodedJarMain, the average time was 5.791 seconds, deviating by 0.460 s/op. 

6. A significantly higher time was observed for PetclinicBenchmark.fatJar, about 36.068 seconds on average, with a standard deviation of 0.585 s/op. 

7. Lastly, for PetclinicBenchmark.noverify, the average time duration was 31.803 seconds. Unfortunately, the standard error wasn't noted here."

Please note that these results indicate average times from ten individual benchmarks, so individual results may vary a bit.

uncivil: I also don't see the value in the change made to register converters exclusively instead of all (`if-else`). civil: I personally struggle to see the benefit of the modification that requires registering converters selectively rather than all-inclusive (via `if-else`). uncivil: Yes, good point, you're right. I underestimated this issue. But I still think, that recalculating the mean on every `getMean()` is a bit too heavy (espescially with a larger window size) for a little helper class. I could imagine two changes, which would prevent the mean from  drifting away. A little bit ugly: don't save the raw values in the array but `value / values.length`. You still have a little inaccuracy when you want to get a certain value (`values[i] * values.length`), but this error is not accum
civil:
Indeed, you've made a valid point there and I must admit that I may have overlooked the significance of the issue at hand. However, I'm of the opinion that recalculating the mean with every `getMean()` could possibly be an overkill, particularly if we're working with a large window size, for a compact helper class such as this. 

I have contemplated a couple of alterations, which could potentially inhibit the mean from skewing. Admittedly, the first suggestion might not be the most elegant: instead of storing raw values in the array, we could rather save `value / values.length`. Although this might lead to a slight deviation when retrieving a specific value (illustrated as `values[i] * values.length`), this discrepancy isn't significant enough to be cumulative.

uncivil: The main problems with .NET serverside running on Mono are: - slow slow cross-AppDomain calls  - crappy implementation of ASP.NET stack.  It has several bottlenecks and non-optimal code. There is http that has some workarounds, but its still slow. - non-optimal System.Net.Sockets (it follows Windows model that is designed for IOCP with thread pool waiting for events, while for Linux it's better to have several worker threads using epoll and handle events in the same thread that got it from the kernel)  Wh
civil:
The predominant challenges that we might confront with .NET server-side running on Mono include: 

- Time-consuming cross-AppDomain calls which can affect performance.
- The implementation of the ASP.NET stack could use some improvements; it has a few bottlenecks and instances of non-optimal code. For example, there are http workarounds, yet it remains somewhat slow.
- The System.Net.Sockets feature is not optimized to its fullest potential. Currently, it follows the Windows model designed for IOCP with a thread pool waiting for events, while on Linux, it would be more efficient to have several worker threads using epoll to handle events in the same thread that receives them from the kernel.

uncivil: the default set supplied in JAF plus the ones they configure via Spring.  Although not quite as comprehensive out of the box, option two has less potential for cacking things up in a J2EE context, plus it keeps configuration inside Spring.  As a real compromise, I can create a FactoryBean that will read the a file in the format you have specified, or in Java properties format (a little nicer I think plus it won't be confused with the JAF file) and inject that into the per message context. civil: maintain your current format or transition to a Java properties format if you choose. The default set from JAF combined with configurations through Spring is another option, but it may be slightly less comprehensive than your proposed solution. However, its potential to create confusion or problems within a J2EE context is less, and it keeps the configurations within Spring. Another potential compromise could be creating a FactoryBean, which would read a file in the format you've specified, or in a Java properties format, which is arguably easier to manage and less likely to cause confusion with the JAF file. This FactoryBean can then be injected into the per message context, allowing you to either continue with your current format or make the shift to a Java properties format if you prefer.

uncivil: > Has there been any progress on this? I'm now in the midst of my third ES implementation and this is the third time this issue came up :) >  > Is #1242 related? It bears the name "Changes API" but seems to resemble something else (notifications for outside ES?). >  > Currently I'm planning to have an alias for writing pointing to multiple indices but doing the writes manually by: >  > * read the aliases to figure out to which indices it points > * write to all these indices in a loop >  > The nasty thing
civil:
is:

1. I was wondering if there has been any advancement on this issue? Currently, I find myself in the process of my third ES implementation and it's the third occasion this issue has surfaced :)

2. Could it be possible that #1242 is related to this? It carries the title "Changes API", however it appears to bear a resemblance to something different (perhaps notifications for outside of ES?). 

3. At present, my strategy involves having an alias that leads to multiple indices, but I'm manually executing the writing process by means of:
   
* Firstly, reading the aliases with the aim of identifying which indices it is pointing towards.
   
* Secondly, individually writing to all of these indices in a looping process. 

One small challenge this presents, however, is:

uncivil: Not only empty queries; a query containing only whitespace will fail too.  It's pretty annoying from a logical POV -- empty strings are nothing special, really. Littering the application code with checks for query emptiness/whitespace-only-ness is very ugly and unnatural.   Should be done on ES side (no query restriction = match all). "400 Bad Request" is not an appropriate response.
civil: Please be aware that it's not just empty queries that will cause issues, queries composed only of whitespace will also fail. While it might seem puzzling at first, given that on a basic level empty strings are nothing extraordinary, the frequent need to pepper application code with checks for query emptiness or those that only contain whitespace does appear rather unsightly and counterintuitive. I believe that such problems could be addressed more effectively on the ES side by applying a 'no query restriction equals match all' rule. The current "400 Bad Request" response doesn't quite seem suitable in my opinion.

uncivil: Your initial submission does not read like a bug report, but like you don't know how to do something in Selenium. We close those issues because there are other places to get help.  If you think you have found a bug, you need to provide a reproducible use case, error message and a stack trace. You provided a bunch of information that won't help us figure out the problem, and not enough information that would. What line of your code caused the error? A generic Python error could be a Selenium issue or somet
civil:
hing else entirely. 

2. The way you structured your comment doesn't make it look like a bug report. It rather looks like a request for guidance or a question on how to use Selenium. We tend to close such issues because there are more appropriate platforms available to offer help in that regard. Now, if your intention is to report a bug, it would be helpful if you could provide specific details including a reproducible use case, the error message received, and a stack trace. Much of the information you have given can't directly guide us towards resolving the issue. There simply isn't enough clarity around what exactly the problem is. Perhaps it would be helpful if you state which line of your code led to the error because a general Python error could arise due to a range of reasons - it could be something specific to Selenium or another unrelated issue altogether.

uncivil: > I vote for C++ to have only one code to rule them all :) Python would be ok too but add a dependency to python for the Java rule so I'd rather not.  Actually another reason to not use PowerShell is that there seems to be some policy that prevents Scripts from being executed by the user (the usual Windows policy hell). We currently wrap our PowerShell inside of batches to workaround that.
civil: I'm inclined to suggest that we utilize C++ as our primary coding language, considering its widespread acceptance and proven versatility. While Python does offer many advantages, it might introduce an unwarranted dependency for any Java-based architecture, which is something I believe we should avoid. Furthermore, I'd like to highlight that our current use of PowerShell does pose challenges, especially due to the prevailing policy that inhibits the execution of scripts by the users. To alleviate this issue, we've been encapsulating our PowerShell scripts within batches. This process, albeit functional, adds layers to our protocol that could be streamlined with a more straightforward, singular coding language.

civil:
It appears that every project I participate in encounters this issue occasionally. It tends to undermine the value of 'git blame' in its primary function. Thus, although I appreciate the concept, its translation into practice can often be rather complicated. We seem to lack sophisticated tools that would allow for automatic formatting during check-ins at the moment. If it's agreeable, I would prefer to avoid this situation wherever possible.

A plausible solution could perhaps be the implementation of git commit hooks and automatic pre-commit formatting, whereby the formatting commanded by the command line and IntelliJ would be governed by the same file. To put it simply: I'm merely suggesting.

uncivil: I can reproduce this on 4.17.0. When accessing the conversation list after a fresh unlock using the new "screen unlock" within the Signal app, pressing the back button will bring the user back to the pattern unlock screen. It doesn't actually re-lock Signal, however.   If you press back again, or press home and then re-enter Signal, the pattern unlock screen is not present and you are taken to your conversation list as expected. If you re-enter your screen unlock pattern while the errant unlock screen is
civil:
present, you do not actually need to re-unlock Signal again. I've logged the issue for investigation.

I wanted to bring to your attention that I was able to replicate this issue using the 4.17.0 version. I observed that when you access the conversation list, immediately after unlocking via the newly introduced "screen unlock" feature in the Signal app, pressing the back button directs the user to the pattern unlock screen. However, interestingly, it does not actually relock Signal. 

Further, if you press the back button again, or push the home button and then navigate back into Signal, the pattern unlock screen does not appear and you are immediately taken to your conversation list as intended. Lastly, if you happen to re-enter your screen unlock pattern when the unexpected unlock screen is present, the application doesn't require you to unlock Signal again. I've taken the liberty to log this concern for further examination.

uncivil: I wanted to add something else too: YouTube wants users to watch as many videos as possible, one after another. Their suggested next video and auto play are all about getting people to watch more adverts. This is one reason why YouTubeKids, and certainly YouTube itself suffers from suggesting utter garbage to kids. NewPipe does not need to concern itself with any of that business model though and should not use the same patterns to show videos.
civil:
I'd like to introduce an additional point here: YouTube's main goal is to encourage users to engage with as many videos as they can in consecutive order. Features such as the suggested next video and autoplay are primarily geared towards promoting greater advertisement exposure. This particular strategy has unfortunately led platforms such as YouTubeKids, and to a larger extent, YouTube itself, to occasionally suggest content of lesser quality to younger audiences. 

However, NewPipe operates independently of such a business model and as such, does not need to emulate these approaches for video presentation. It's imperative that we do our utmost to ensure a diverse, high-quality content offering that respects our viewers' time, interests, and intelligence.

uncivil: I think I found the **root cause**: the **libtool crap in freeswitch** (again). configure finds libopusenc and declares the related defs. however, when mod_opusfile.c gets compiled, they are simply not used. And therefore the [write file part](https://github.com/signalwire/freeswitch/blob/master/src/mod/formats/mod_opusfile/mod_opusfile.c#L222) of it gets skipped and a generic error returned, without giving any log message about the reason =8-( . It finally gets linked against libopusenc, but that's obvio
civil: I believe that I've uncovered the primary issue; there appears to be a complication within the libtool portion of freeswitch. Upon observation, it was noticed that the configure recognizes libopusenc and subsequently declares the related definitions. However, when mod_opusfile.c is compiled, those definitions are not utilized as one would anticipate. Consequently, the process of writing files is overlooked, resulting in a vague error without any log message communicating the reason for the mishap. At the end of the process, it is linked against libopusenc, but that might be rather evident from the issue at hand.

civil: There's currently a security exception due to only `jaas_nt` being included at the moment. Our team is actively working on adjustments, and you can monitor the progress on this link provided: http. To shed more light on this issue, we've noticed a glitch in our management of slf4j that impacts hadoop. Although it isn't included in any ES distributions, our build system treats it as `provided`. This means it isn't included in any plugin that requires it. There's a temporary workaround for this, but it needs a permanent fix soon. I'm going to test your minihdfs cluster manually and aim to improve the integration, such as connection, snapshotting, and restoring. Please feel free to contact Ryan if you need further information about this.

civil:

This is further solidified by the debugging confirmation [org.jgroups.protocols.pbcast.GMS[]] for 'keycloak-cache-init' with the specific address test-keycloak-x-2-37948 within the cluster ISPN. However, one significant line that deserves special attention. It confirms that the configuration was properly loaded. An informational message [org.infinispan.CLUSTER] at 00:31:51 signifies it. I hope this helps and feel free to reach out if you have more inquiries.

uncivil: {name|*|_all|blank}/_mappings|_aliases|_warmers|_settings ```  ## `DELETE`  ### Option 1  Make the `DELETE` available for 3 APIs like in `_warmer`:  ```  DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/name   DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/prefix*   DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/ ```  ### Option 2:  Leave everything as is.
civil:
To: {name}

Subject: Suggestions Regarding DELETE Availability for APIs

Dear {name},

Hope this message finds you well.

I have been giving much thought to our current system format and would like to propose two potential options to consider:

Option 1: 

We could consider extending the availability of the `DELETE` command to three APIs, similar to its current functionality in `_warmer`. This might look like:

```
DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/name 
DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/prefix* 
DELETE index/_mapping|_alias|_warmer/
```
This alteration could potentially streamline some processes, by allowing the `DELETE` command to serve a more comprehensive purpose.

Option 2:

Alternatively, we could choose to retain our existing structure as is. This option does not offer the extents of modification suggested in Option 1, yet it also requires no adaptation on part of the team.

Please feel free to share your thoughts on these suggestions. Both options have their merits, and I welcome your input to help determine which may be the most beneficial for our system's overall efficiency and functionality.

Looking forward to our discussion.

Best Regards,

[Your Name]

uncivil: > it sucks that we need to implement grow-ability to save cost of zeroing out where we already have allocated all the memory or is there any other advantage?.  The problem is the memory is not initialized when we allocated it, so it has garbage in it, and therefore we need to initialize the parts we're going to use. And initialization can take a while if your buffer size is big (like a gigabyte, as some people do).  > Instead, if we reserved numBucket bytes at the start of buffer and used those for markin
civil: I understand the need to implement grow-ability to optimize the costs that are associated with zeroing out memory once it's completely allocated. However, I was wondering if there are any additional benefits to this approach. The issue that I'm seeing is that the memory isn't initialized following allocation, which results in undesired data, and we subsequently have to initialize the sections we're going to use. Initializations could potentially be time-consuming if your buffer size is large, such as a gigabyte, which is not uncommon. Perhaps we could consider reserving numBucket bytes at the start of the buffer and utilize these for marking.

uncivil: Hi Simon,  I guess I used to much 'I need support' trigger words?  My issue was: holy crap, ES is dropping indices after a restart of a single node. This sounds like a bug right?  Anyways I've done some more digging and think I have found something interesting for you. It seems that the dangling indices got deleted by curator. Some 7 hours later one node got restarted and the deleted indices reappeared, but without data, so cluster got red. Thats a bug to me.  Lets take one of those dangling indices as ex
civil:
Hello Simon,

I hope you're doing well. Perhaps I may have overused the phrase 'I need support' in our previous connection? I'm experiencing an issue that I'd like to bring to your attention. After restarting a single node, ElasticSearch seems to be dropping indices - it sounds like it might be a potential bug or inconsistency.

I have continued to explore the issue and I believe I have found some useful information that may interest you. It appears the deleted indices, often referred to as 'dangling indices', were eliminated by the Curator. Strikingly, these indices reappeared about seven hours following the restart of one node. However, they came back with no data which caused the cluster to turn red. From my understanding, this occurrence might be a bug.

Possible discussions revolving around these dangling indices could add more light to our investigation and resolution strategy. Thank you in advance for your assistance.

uncivil: @user   `ByteBuffer.allocate()` is used 152 times, `allocateDirect()` - 6 times, `Files.map()` - 9 times.  > We already have a finalize in Memory incase someone forgets to free explicitly. Finalize will be slower, but it is very infrequent.   - The problem is OOMs because of inability to reclaim finalizable objects on a given GC phase. Allocating larger objects only makes it worse.  - Currently StupidPool of ByteBuffers allocates as many ByteBuffers as ResourceHolders, the effect of changing that resource
civil:
1. @user, it's worth noting that `ByteBuffer.allocate()` is used 152 times, while `allocateDirect()` is used only 6 times and `Files.map()` - 9 times. Our current setup does include a finalize function in Memory, which operates as a safety net in case an explicit free instruction is missed. The downside is that finalize tends to work slower, although it doesn't come into play very frequently. 

The main issue we encounter is the Out of Memory errors which can occur due to the system's failure to reclaim objects pending finalization during a specific Garbage Collection phase. Having larger objects would only further complicate this situation. Right now, the StupidPool feature for ByteBuffers is configured to allocate ByteBuffers equivalent to the number of ResourceHolders. It might be worth discussing the impact and potential benefits of modifying this resource allocation pattern.

uncivil: *Original comment by @user  I spend some more days thinking about this and I'm still worried that the solution we came up with is too "messy": 1. It adds complexity to a place which is already complex - i.e., templates.  2. When an indexing requests comes and the string in the url doesn't resolve to an index or an alias,  we translate it internally to a create index request where the string is set in the index name. Based on the solution, the master will then resolve the incoming index name parameter firs
civil:
*Revised comment by @user 

After taking a few more days to deeply contemplate our proposed solution, I must express my continued concerns. I'm apprehensive that our solution could potentially introduce an element of disorderliness:

1. There seems to be an unwarranted layer of complexity being added to an already intricate system, specifically the templates. 

2. Considering the scenario where an indexing request comes along, and the string in the URL doesn't resolve to an index or an alias, our proposed solution seems to mandate an internal translation to a 'create index' request, where this string is defined in the index name. Judging by the proposed workflow, the master will seemingly need to first resolve the incoming index name parameter.

uncivil: eb already has too many other variables adding a few milliseconds here and > there to worry about rare maximums that are still quite low in the big > picture. >  > (That said, I realize that the particular case we are discussing, Go 1.0.3 > at 256 concurrency, may in fact have some requests at greater than 2,000ms > that are missed by the Wrk latency sampler, suggesting perhaps a garbage > collection hiccup.) >  > I would like to eventually understand why when Wrk completes each request > it cannot simply
civil:
cycle through the completed requests and count the latency for each one > separately, but that's a different issue entirely. 

Taking everything into consideration with EB, there is indeed quite a bit to manage given that we already have to take into account a multitude of variables. Moreover, we are also dealing with the addition of a few milliseconds here and there. Nonetheless, given the broader picture, these rare maximums are still rather minimal.

While keeping in mind the specific case we are looking at, Go 1.0.3 at 256 concurrency, it's possible there might be some requests exceeding 2,000ms, an aspect which may have escaped the notice of the Wrk latency sampler. This could hint towards a minor garbage collection hiccup.

In future, I am eager to delve deeper into the reason why it isn't possible for Wrk to review each completed request individually and calculate the latency separately. However, I do admit that this is indeed a different issue altogether.

uncivil: Ugh...  In http we disabled instrumenting androidx.* packages by default. It's a nice performance improvement. But it seems that there's some logic in Espresso that was inadvertently relying on Robolectric's instrumentation to strip 'final' modifiers to be able to access final fields androidx.loader.content.ModernAsyncTask. To fix this issue temporarily, you can add:  ``` @user     instrumentedPackages = {       // required to access final members on androidx.loader.content.ModernAsyncTask       "androidx

max_participants_in_merge=100max_interval=30000 only_coords_run_consistency_checker=false) :FD_SOCK(cache_max_age=10000 get_cache_timeout=1000
sock_conn_timeout=1000 client_bind_port=0 ergonomics=true start_port=0 port_range=50 suspect_msg_interval=5000 num_tries=3 stats=true external_port=0 bind_addr=IP_ADDRESS keep_alive=true
Id=2 cache_max_elements=200) :FD_ALL(use_time_service=true stats=true timeout_check_interval=1000 ergonomics=true interval=2000 id=20 timeout=10000) :VERIFY_SUSPECT(num_msgs=1
civil:
It appears that you've adjusted various parameters. Let's review these new settings:

- You've set the maximum number of participants in a merge at 100 while the maximum interval is set to 30000. Also, the consistency checker will only run for coordinates, is that correct?
- For `FD_SOCK`, you've modified the cache maximum age to 10000 and both the cache timeout and socket connection timeout to 1000. You've also set `client_bind_port` at 0, enabled the `ergonomics` feature, and defined the start port as 0 with a port range of 50. You've also adjusted the suspect message interval to 5000 and the number of tried at 3. You've enabled statistics and have an external port set as 0. 
- For binding address, have you assigned it a valid IP address? 
- You're keeping the connection alive, right? The cache has a maximum element of 200 and the identification is set as 2, is this your desired configuration?
- Moving onto `FD_ALL`, having time service enabled enhances performance, a good decision indeed. You've set statistical gathering as active, set the timeout check interval at 1000 and the interval at 2000. And you've set the identification as 20 with a timeout of 10000. 
- Finally, regarding the `VERIFY_SUSPECT` function, you've set the number of messages to 1.

Please confirm these changes are correct, and if there are any fields you would like for us to delve deeper into, feel free to share.

uncivil: ly want to avoid: - Other apps reading our files (which you don't get in 'internal storage') - Storing unencrypted copies of encrypted content - The app crashing without explanation if an SD card with all the settings and stuff on being removed  I also think that asking users to provide the path for 'external storage' is bad UX anyway. Using a file browser would be better. This whole setting needs ripping out and improving in a backward compatible manner.  There's lots of related improvements to do in thi
civil:
I wish to suggest some areas of modification for this app from a user's perspective. First, it is essential to prevent other applications from accessing our files. This is a feature seamlessly provided by 'internal storage'. Second, there should not be any unencrypted versions of encrypted content. Additionally, app crashes can be frustrating, particularly if an SD card, containing all the settings and data is removed. 

On another note, I feel that requiring users to provide the path for 'external storage' adds a layer of complexity to the user experience. It would be beneficial to consider implementing a file browser. Lastly, developing and enhancing the settings in a manner which is backward compatible may provide a more smooth and user-friendly interface. There are numerous related improvements that can be made, and these suggestions are a starting point.

uncivil: ://demo.doit.com.sa) > > Regarding this issue the correct and cross platform way to open the > keyboard is to issue "focus()" on native html input(text), we set this to > absolute and top:-1000px , also important to note that iOS (8.0+) will only > open keyboard if executed from within user action and for that you need to > run this from "touchDown" in libGDX (very important). > > â€” > You are receiving this because you modified the open/close state. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > <htt
civil:
Hello there,

In relation to the topic at hand, the most appropriate and universally applicable method to prompt the keyboard to open is to implement the "focus()" command on native HTML input (text). For this, we arrange it to be absolute and top: -1000px. It's important to mention that iOS (version 8.0 upwards) will only initiate the keyboard if the command is executed within user action. As such, you'll need to execute this within "touchDown" in libGDX, which is of great significance.

Take note that you've received this message because there were modifications made to the open/close condition. Please feel free to reply directly to this email or view this information on Github.

uncivil: e whole system into a uber-FUBAR state - Elasticsearch complaining about it cannot write logs, sent via rsyslog to our Logstashes; Elasticsearch writing millions of `data/write`s into audit-logs, which then are scraped by filebeat...  This means that Filebeat is never able to keep up with scraping all needed logs from that audit.json.  We need to be able to filter events **before** they get written to the logfile easily. Also I observed high CPU usage by Filebeat already, only with this meager `processors
civil: The current system seems to be in a highly disorganized state - Elasticsearch is having difficulties in writing logs, which are transmitted through rsyslog to our Logstashes. Additionally, Elasticsearch is logging millions of `data/write` operations into audit-logs, making it a challenge for Filebeat to  stay abreast with all the required logs from that audit.json. It would be more effective if we could filter events prior to them being logged into the logfile. On another note, I've observed that Filebeat is already utilizing high CPU resources, even with its current basic `processors`.

uncivil: Yea, I understand. What travis-ci means by "failed" is "anything that was not a 100% pass", whereas I think a number of people see "holy crap I broke the build". Sadly there are a number of cases where we (quite sanely, I like to think) would prefer to have a greyed-out "this build didn't make sense for some reason, but that's probably ok"
civil: Yes, I do acknowledge your view. To elaborate, Travis-CI uses the term "failed" to indicate any result that is not a complete 100% pass. Contrarily, there seems to be a common perception that it signifies a more catastrophic breakdown, as expressed in terms like "I absolutely ruined the build". It's worth pointing out that in certain instances, we might sensibly prefer a more nuanced notification such as "this build didn't quite turn out as expected which could be acceptable under specific circumstances".

uncivil: @user :  I am going to answer your questions here instead of spreading them across several issues.  > @user wrote in http >  > @user >  > why is TextSecure's "Emoji experience" good and native Android's "Emoji experience" bad, IYHO?  IMHO the native Android Emoji experience is bad because it is very inconsistent.  HTC Android devices are using their own HTC Emoji set, Samsung Android devices are using their own Samsung Emoji set, LG Android devices are using their own LG Emoji set, Google Android devices
civil:
are using their own Google Emoji set. This results in a fragmented experience where the same Emoji can look and mean different things on different devices. 

On the other hand, TextSecure's Emoji experience is universally the same across all devices, ensuring consistency and eliminating any potential misunderstandings that could arise from different Emoji interpretations. This is why I believe the "Emoji experience" offered by TextSecure is superior to the native Android one.

uncivil: off heap memory use, we decided to start Bisq on Linux and OSX with this jvm option:  `-XX:MaxRAM=4g"`.  That means Bisq's JVM normally uses about 25% of the maximum RAM limit, or about 1 Gb.  The upside is Bisq users' computers are not liable to crash because of Bisq, but it increases the risk Bisq may run out of memory, and throw an `OutOfMemoryException`. See the **Setting JVM's MaxRAM** section of this comment for a few details.      2.  A long chain sync at startup locks up the UI thread until it's d
civil:
1. Considering the use of off-heap memory, we have made the decision to initiate Bisq on Linux and OSX using the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) option `-XX:MaxRAM=4g`. This signifies that Bisq's JVM is likely to use approximately 25% of the maximum RAM limit, equating to about 1 Gb. On the bright side, this ensures that Bisq will not cause users' computers to crash. However, there is an elevated possibility that Bisq might exhaust its memory, thus resulting in an `OutOfMemoryException`. Please consult the **Setting JVM's MaxRAM** section of this commentary for additional information.

2. At startup, an extended chain sync can temporarily suspend the UI thread until it's completed.

uncivil: using `static import` won't work anyway cause java is a terrible language.  You will get an error like this:  > The method translate(float, float) in the type JavaSucks is not applicable for the arguments (PVector)  This is a thing that is always driving me nuts, I program libraries where everything is static. civil: Using `static import` may not always work as expected due to some features of Java. One might encounter errors such as:  > The method translate(float, float) in the type JavaSucks is not applicable for the arguments (PVector)  This can sometimes be challenging, especially when programming libraries where everything is static. To overcome this, I often use prefixes like `_draw` to avoid conflict with Processing's `draw` method, for example. In my perception, it could possibly be a design decision or maybe an oversight, but it's been around for a while.

uncivil: anDefinitionParser does not allow us to inject a     * custom HttpMessageConverter. Look at SPR-7091 on jira.springframework.org     * !!!     */     if (bean instanceof AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter) {          AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter adapter = (AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter) bean       HttpMessageConverter<?>[] converters = adapter.getMessageConverters()       List<HttpMessageConverter<?>> cs = new ArrayList<HttpMessageConverter<?>>()        for (HttpMessageConverter<?> converter : converter
civil:
I must point out that the anDefinitionParser does not give us the provision to inject a custom HttpMessageConverter. This issue is relevant to SPR-7091 on jira.springframework.org. In case the bean is an instance of AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter, we can opt for the following approach:
 
An AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter adapter gets instantiated by the bean, after which the getMessageConverters() method retrieves an array of HttpMessageConverters. Then, a new empty ArrayList of HttpMessageConverter gets created. Subsequently, a for-each loop iterates over each converter.

uncivil: ToS are not law - it just means that if you violate them, youtube is free to withhold their services to you (i.e. terminate your account & block your IP if they're extra mean) - it only becomes illegal if you agree to the ToS by using their services through their official clients (i.e. the website, the regular app, etc.)  Cease and Desist letters don't have to have any reason to exist; just the threat of a legal battle which Google would 100% lose would stop any development being done on Newpipe, since no
civil:
Terms of Service are not a form of legislation but rather a contract between you and the service provider such as Youtube. If you violate these terms, Youtube has the discretion to withdraw their services to you, which might extend to terminating your account or blocking your IP. This is not necessarily illegal unless you had agreed to the ToS through their official channels like the website or application.

As for Cease and Desist letters, they do not need to be backed by a concrete reason. The mere prospect of a legal tussle, which Google is very likely to lose, would cease any progress on Newpipe. This is simply because itâ€™s rarely feasible for individuals or small teams to stand against corporate giants in court.

civil:
Rather than firmly committing to an API that dictates how we interpret these files, I would suggest a more flexible approach. We could either implement a preprocessing step that converts them into .bzl format, or utilize a repo rule as recommended by @user. Unfortunately, the workaround I proposed earlier might be somewhat inconvenient, even for those well-versed in Bazel. 

Allow me to propose a very hands-on API method for reading file content. For example: ```bzl load_text(":version.txt", "VERSION") ```
It's worth mentioning that Starlark already has 'json.decode', therefore JSON would automatically be supported. Here's an instance of how we could use it: ```bzl load_text...```

Arguably, much better and broader than anything the Selenium project volunteers could cobble together on their own.  ### We should do less  I would love to see a PR that removes about 90% of what's currently published on the seleniumhq.org site.  The docs there are much too ambitious, trying to handle stuff like best-practices, test design patterns, test philosophy, etc.  In my ideal world, for a project this size, documentation maintained by the project would ju
civil:
st be the API: http://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/java/index.html (or whatever your language of choice is).  Browsers, today, are a platform of reasonable richness and stability, so stop.  Resist the urge to complicate matters by micro-managing everything.  You do you! - No one.

1. There's a plethora of resources available for learning, some of which arguably offer a wider and more comprehensive understanding than what our Selenium project volunteers might be able to assemble on their own.

### We should consider simplifying

I would be thrilled to see a proposal that aims to reduce around 90% of the content currently available on the seleniumhq.org site. The documentation there seems to take on a rather ambitious approach, with attempts to cover diverse topics such as best-practices, test design patterns, and test philosophy, etc.

In my optimal scenario for a project of this scale, the documentation maintained by the project would primarily focus on the API: http://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/java/index.html (or depending on your preferred language).

Nowadays, browsers offer a fairly rich and stable platform, so maybe we should refrain from overcomplicating things by micromanaging. Just be true to yourselves! - Anonymous.

uncivil: It need to be fiat currency sufficiently trades, so EUR or USD are the only one which always got some volume. We calculate the historical price based on those trades. The calculation is a bit expensive so I dont want to do it for multiple currencies. Also for most USD price is kind of the main price metric. Does not mean any endoresement of USD of course - the biggest shitcoin in fiat land. ;-)
civil: To establish a stable transaction, it's typically preferred to trade with fiat currencies that have a substantial trading volume, like the Euro and the US dollar. Our method for calculating historical prices is based on these trades. The calculation process, however, can be rather resource-intensive, which is why we don't prefer to do it for multiple currencies. Moreover, it's generally observed that the US dollar price is more frequently used as a primary price metric. This doesn't imply any particular endorsement of the USD though. After all, each fiat currency has its unique aspects that we must consider.

yes, on, off, etc are supported because of the YAML spec: http  This doesn't mean we have to allow them. There are other things in the YAML spec we may not allow too. This isn't inconsistent, its the same as YAML only allowing certain whitespace characters, despite requiring a Unicode text encoding. They don't have to allow all Unicode whitespace just because Unicode defines whitespace in a certain way.  If we think the boolean settings being parsed are all unimportant, then by all means, stick with a cr
civil: Absolutely, terms like "on", "off", etc. are indeed supported thanks to the specifications outlined by YAML: [http link provided]. However, this doesn't automatically imply that we are obliged to allow them. Just like there could be certain aspects in the YAML specifications that we may choose not to accommodate. This doesn't particularly amount to inconsistency, it parallels the fact that though YAML permits only specific whitespace characters, despite necessitating a Unicode text encoding. This doesn't mean YAML needs to accommodate all Unicode whitespace just because Unicode identifies whitespace in a specific manner. Now, if we believe that the boolean settings being analyzed are not particularly crucial, then we might as well continue with the current approach.

uncivil: n loggingPrefs map * `--log-level=LEVEL` without log-path still has default logging set to dev/null and does not respect anything in loggingPrefs map  ### Options: 1. Selenium updates code to not go to dev/null when log level is set but log file is not. This isn't really related to the problem specified, but is a place where intent is not being respected --> Yes  2. Selenium updates code to add a default log level when a log file is specified. Whatever level chosen would override what is set in loggingPre
civil:
1. I've observed that even without a log-path set, the 'n loggingPrefs map * `--log-level=LEVEL` still defaults to dev/null and it seems to not comply with the parameters set in the loggingPrefs map. 

There are a couple of potential solutions for this:

Firstly, it might be helpful if Selenium could adjust their code such that it doesn't default to dev/null when a log level is assigned but no log file is specified. While this isn't directly connected to the issue at hand, it seems to be an area where our intention isn't fully carried out.

Alternatively, Selenium could revise their code to include a default log level when a log file is specified. Whichever level chosen, it would then supersede the settings in loggingPrefs.

uncivil: `--define` is more than just `goog.define`s. You can also have non-Closure `@define`s (like `COMPILED` in base.js). A bundle won't replace these and it doesn't make sense for them to go in `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES`. I think it would be confusing if `--define` always set the Closure defines as a result.  There are work arounds, obviously. You can pass an input to the compiler that sets `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES` and it will 1) output that to the bundle and 2) respect that in a compile. Then it is
civil: The utility of `--define` extends beyond `goog.define`s. It also embraces non-Closure `@define`s, like `COMPILED` found in our base.js. Due to their nature, a bundle is incapable of substituting these, and it would be illogical to lodge them under `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES`. If we always allowed `--define` to determine the Closure defines, it might create confusion. However, it's important to note there are solutions to this. For example, an input could be provided to the compiler to adjust `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES`, which would consequently 1) include that into the bundle, and 2) acknowledge it during the compiling process. Therefore, this continuity is maintained.

uncivil: So what roundcube does here is that it creates clearsigned messages, and wraps them in an encrypted mime part. This is in essence a bastard between pgp/mime and pgp/inline, combining the worst of both worlds. I wonder what they do if you add an attachment?  Either way, while it would be possible to support this for robustness' sake, I firmly believe we should make a decision not to, making sure this format dies as quickly as possible. Closing this issue, if anyone disagrees feel free to reopen.  (btw, mut
civil: What RoundCube appears to do here is produce clearsigned messages and envelop them in an encrypted MIME part. In essence, this seems like a hybrid of PGP/MIME and PGP/Inline, combining significant challenges from both. I'm curious about their handling of attachments in such a scenario. While we could certainly add support for this to ensure our system's robustness, I would suggest that we intentionally choose not to. It seems to be in our best interest to ensure this format doesn't persist any longer than necessary. With this in mind, I'm closing this issue. Should anyone disagree or want to discuss further, please feel free to reopen the topic.

uncivil: @user You need to add `.toWebElement()`:  ```java actions().moveToElement($(".gsfi").toWebElement()).perform(); ```  The point is that `$(".gsfi")` is not a "real" `WebElement`, but a proxy object (created by Selenide). If you call "usual" methods on this proxy objects, everything works.  But actions builder doesn't call "usual" methods, but uses black magic (which fails with the proxy object).  Namely, actions builder calls `BeanToJsonConverter` which uses reflection and iterates all _properties_ of give
civil:
n object. 

Dear @user, it might be beneficial if you could add `.toWebElement()` as such: 

```java 
actions().moveToElement($(".gsfi").toWebElement()).perform(); 
```

This is due to `$(".gsfi")` not being a conventional `WebElement`, but rather a proxy object generated by Selenide. Ordinarily, this proxy object performs as expected when typical methods are applied to it.

However, the actions builder behaves differently as it does not use conventional methods but rather relies on a more intricate process (which unfortunately falls flat with the proxy object). Specifically, the actions builder calls `BeanToJsonConverter` which utilizes reflection and iterates all the properties of the given object. I hope this clarification helps!

uncivil: @user I think we might already be at peak-workaround. The webrtc folks, in their infinite wisdom, do not seem to think it's important to support "ringing." As soon as I build a PeerConnection, it tries to take over and play an AudioTrack w/ STREAM_VOICE_CALL whether the AudioTrack is enabled or not.  If I try to play sounds with MODE_RINGTONE, they'll just get hijacked by webrtc and end up in the earpiece.  The only thing I can do is play the ringtone into the voice call stream, but turn the speaker on.
civil: @user, I believe we might have reached the maximum capacity of dealing with improvised solutions here. It appears that the professionals behind WebRTC do not prioritize the support for "ringing." Whenever I construct a PeerConnection, it endeavours to dominate and play an AudioTrack with STREAM_VOICE_CALL, regardless of the AudioTrack's status. If I attempt to use MODE_RINGTONE to play sounds, they are typically overridden by WebRTC and directed to the earpiece. The only viable solution I see is to route the ringtone into the call stream whilst enabling the speaker.

uncivil: Gerrit already requires a patched version of buck that is 4 commits ahead of your tree. I just keep rebasing and fixing the same damn merge conflicts. Now we have 5 commits ahead, the latest one replaces "." as the top of the source tree with the absolute path because "." as the project root late becomes "/./" in some path strings and buck isn't fully prepared for this. _sigh_  The java_library() not accepting a genfile() in a package name is now patched around by having the genrule() spit out a JAR by ru
civil: Just to bring to your attention, Gerrit currently uses a patched version of buck that is already 4 commits ahead of your tree. I've been consistently rebasing and addressing the recurring merge conflicts. Now, we're 5 commits ahead. The most recent one substitutes "." at the start of the source tree with the absolute path. This is because "." as the project root later converts into "/./" in some path strings and it seems buck is not fully equipped for this situation. The issue with java_library() not accepting a genfile() in a package name has been temp-fixed by modifying the genrule() to output a JAR by running it manually.

civil: It seems that it isn't as initially perceived. When we run this command : `shell $ curl -XGET http`, we can observe that the response we receive is positive - `"ok": true`. It unveils that our cluster name is "graylog2" and it also shows us the details of the nodes existing within this cluster. For instance, "Freakmaster" appears to be one of the nodes and all necessary details for it, like its transport address, hostname, version and http address, are visible. Likewise, we can see the properties of the other nodes such as "Hammer, Justin" along with its corresponding transport address.
